Tang Shu Yu of Jin was a son of King Wu of Zhou and the younger brother of King Cheng. Initially, when King Wu met with Shu Yu's mother, he dreamed that heaven told King Wu: 'I command this woman to give birth to a son named Yu. I give him Tang.' When she gave birth to the son, there was writing on his hand that said 'Yu'. Therefore they followed this and named him Yu.

æ­¦ç‹å´©ï¼Œæˆç‹ç«‹ï¼Œå”æœ‰äº‚ï¼Œå‘¨å…¬èª…æ»…å”ã€‚ æˆç‹èˆ‡å”è™æˆ²ï¼Œå‰Šæ¡è‘‰ç‚ºçªä»¥èˆ‡å”è™ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œä»¥æ­¤å°è‹¥ã€‚ã€ å²ä½šå› è«‹æ“‡æ—¥ç«‹å”è™ã€‚ æˆç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾èˆ‡ä¹‹æˆ²è€³ã€‚ã€ å²ä½šæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤©å­ç„¡æˆ²è¨€ã€‚ è¨€å‰‡å²æ›¸ä¹‹ï¼Œç¦®æˆä¹‹ï¼Œæ¨‚æ­Œä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯é‚å°å”è™æ–¼å”ã€‚ å”åœ¨æ²³ã€æ±¾ä¹‹æ±ï¼Œæ–¹ç™¾é‡Œï¼Œæ•…æ›°å”å”è™ã€‚ å§“å§¬æ°ï¼Œå­—å­äºã€‚
King Wu passed away. King Cheng ascended the throne. Tang rebelled. The Duke of Zhou executed the rebels and extinguished Tang. King Cheng played with Shu Yu. He carved a paulownia leaf into a gui tablet to give to Shu Yu, saying: 'With this I enfeoff you.' Shi Yi then requested that an auspicious day be selected for establishing Shu Yu. King Cheng said: 'I was just playing with him.' Shi Yi said: 'The tian zi has no playing words. Words then the historians write them, rites complete them, music sings them.' Thus Shu Yu was enfeoffed at Tang. Tang was located east of the Yellow River and Fen River, comprising a square area of one hundred li. Therefore he was called Tang Shu Yu. He bore the surname Ji. His courtesy name was Zi Yu.
3
å”å”å­ç‡®ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ™‰ä¾¯ã€‚ æ™‰ä¾¯å­å¯§æ—ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ­¦ä¾¯ã€‚ æ­¦ä¾¯ä¹‹å­æœäººï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæˆä¾¯ã€‚ æˆä¾¯å­ç¦ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºå²ä¾¯ã€‚ å²ä¾¯ä¹‹å­å®œè‡¼ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºé–ä¾¯ã€‚ é–ä¾¯å·²ä¾†ï¼Œå¹´ç´€å¯æ¨ã€‚ è‡ªå”å”è‡³é–ä¾¯äº”ä¸–ï¼Œç„¡å…¶å¹´æ•¸ã€‚
Tang Shu's son Xie became the Marquis of Jin. The Marquis of Jin's son Ning Zu became Marquis Wu. Marquis Wu's son Fu Ren became Marquis Cheng. Marquis Cheng's son Fu became Marquis Li. Marquis Li's son Yi Jiu became Marquis Jing. From Marquis Jing onward, the chronology can be reliably traced. From Tang Shu to Marquis Jing spanned five generations, but their exact years are not recorded.

é–ä¾¯åä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œå‘¨å²ç‹è¿·æƒ‘æš´è™ï¼Œåœ‹äººä½œäº‚ï¼Œå²ç‹å‡ºå¥”äºå½˜ï¼Œå¤§è‡£è¡Œæ”¿ï¼Œæ•…æ›°ã€Œå…±å’Œã€ã€‚
In Jing Hou's seventeenth year, King Li of Zhou was bewildered and tyrannically cruel. The state people made rebellion. King Li fled to Zhi. Ministers administered the government. Therefore it was called 'Gong He'.

åå…«å¹´ï¼Œé–ä¾¯å’ï¼Œå­é‡ä¾¯å¸å¾’ç«‹ã€‚ é‡ä¾¯åå››å¹´ï¼Œå‘¨å®£ç‹åˆç«‹ã€‚ åå…«å¹´ï¼Œé‡ä¾¯å’ï¼Œå­ç»ä¾¯ç±ç«‹ã€‚ ç»ä¾¯åä¸€å¹´å’ï¼Œå­ç©†ä¾¯è²»ç‹ç«‹ã€‚
In the eighteenth year, Marquis Jing passed away, and his son Si Tu ascended as Marquis Xi. In the fourteenth year of Marquis Xi's rule, King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne. In the eighteenth year, Marquis Xi passed away, and his son Ji ascended as Marquis Xian. Marquis Xian died in his eleventh year of rule, and his son Fei Wang ascended as Marquis Mu.

ç©†ä¾¯å››å¹´ï¼Œå–é½Šå¥³å§œæ°ç‚ºå¤«äººã€‚ ä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œä¼æ¢ã€‚ ç”Ÿå¤ªå­ä»‡ã€‚ åå¹´ï¼Œä¼åƒç•ï¼Œæœ‰åŠŸã€‚ ç”Ÿå°‘å­ï¼Œåæ›°æˆå¸«ã€‚ æ™‰äººå¸«æœæ›°ï¼šã€Œç•°å“‰ï¼Œå›ä¹‹å‘½å­ä¹Ÿï¼ å¤ªå­æ›°ä»‡ï¼Œä»‡è€…è®ä¹Ÿã€‚ å°‘å­æ›°æˆå¸«ï¼Œæˆå¸«å¤§è™Ÿï¼Œæˆä¹‹è€…ä¹Ÿã€‚ åè‡ªå‘½ä¹Ÿï¼› ç‰©è‡ªå®šä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šé©åº¶ååé€†ï¼Œæ­¤å¾Œæ™‰å…¶èƒ½æ¯‹äº‚ä¹ï¼Ÿã€
In the fourth year of Marquis Mu's rule, he took a Jiang woman from Qi as his consort. In the seventh year, he attacked the state of Tiao. She gave birth to the crown prince Qiu. In the tenth year, he attacked Qian Mu and achieved victory. She gave birth to a younger son named Cheng Shi. The Jin person Shi Fu said: 'Strange, how the lord names his sons!' The crown prince is named Qiu. Qiu means 'enemy' or 'adversary.' The younger son is named Cheng Shi. 'Cheng Shi' is an auspicious titleâ€”it means 'the one who will accomplish great things.' Names are their own fate; Things will determine themselves. Now the legitimate and concubine names are contrary and perverse. After this, can Jin not have chaos?'

In the twenty-seventh year, Marquis Mu passed away. His younger brother Shang Shu usurped the throne. Crown Prince Qiu fled into exile. In the third year of Shang Shu's rule, King Xuan of Zhou passed away. In the fourth year, Crown Prince Qiu of Marquis Mu led his followers in an attack on Shang Shu, overthrew him, and established himself as ruler, becoming Marquis Wen.

In the tenth year of Marquis Wen's rule, King You of Zhou ruled tyrannically. The Quanrong barbarians killed King You. The Zhou court moved eastward. And Qin Xiang Gong was first elevated to the rank of feudal lord.

In the thirty-fifth year, Marquis Wen Qiu passed away, and his son Bo ascended as Marquis Zhao.

In the first year of Marquis Zhao's rule, he enfeoffed his uncle Cheng Shi at Quwo. The city of Quwo was larger than Yi. Yi was the Jin ruler's capital city. Cheng Shi was enfeoffed at Quwo and given the title Uncle Huan. Luan Bin, a grandson of Marquis Jing through a concubine, served as minister to Uncle Huan. At this time Uncle Huan was fifty-eight years old and renowned for his virtue. All the people of Jin attached themselves to him. The gentleman said: 'Jin's chaos is perhaps at Qu Wo.' The branch is larger than the root and obtains the people's hearts. If not chaos, what does it wait for!'

ä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰å¤§è‡£æ½˜çˆ¶å¼’å…¶å›æ˜­ä¾¯è€Œè¿æ›²æ²ƒæ¡“å”ã€‚ æ¡“å”æ¬²å…¥æ™‰ï¼Œæ™‰äººç™¼å…µæ”»æ¡“å”ã€‚ æ¡“å”æ•—ï¼Œé‚„æ­¸æ›²æ²ƒã€‚ æ™‰äººå…±ç«‹æ˜­ä¾¯å­å¹³ç‚ºå›ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºå­ä¾¯ã€‚ èª…æ½˜çˆ¶ã€‚
In the seventh year, the Jin minister Pan Fu assassinated his ruler Marquis Zhao and welcomed Uncle Huan of Quwo. Uncle Huan wished to enter the Jin capital. The Jin people dispatched troops to attack Uncle Huan. Uncle Huan was defeated and retreated back to Quwo. The Jin people united to install Ping, son of Marquis Zhao, as their ruler, who became Marquis Xiao. They executed Pan Fu.

In the eighth year of Marquis Xiao's rule, Uncle Huan of Quwo passed away. His son Jia succeeded him as Uncle Huan and became known as Zhuang Bo of Quwo. In the fifteenth year of Marquis Xiao's rule, Zhuang Bo of Quwo assassinated his lord Marquis Xiao of Jin at Yi. The Jin people attacked Zhuang Bo of Quwo. Zhuang Bo retreated back into Quwo. The Jin people once again installed Xi, son of Marquis Xiao, as their ruler, who became Marquis E.

Marquis E died in his sixth year of rule. Zhuang Bo of Quwo heard that Marquis E of Jin had died, so he raised troops to attack Jin. King Ping of Zhou ordered Duke Guo to lead troops against Zhuang Bo of Quwo. Zhuang Bo fled back to defend Quwo. The Jin people united to install Guang, son of Marquis E, as their ruler, who became Marquis Ai.

In the second year of Marquis Ai's rule, Zhuang Bo of Quwo died. His son Cheng succeeded him and became known as Wu Gong of Quwo. In the sixth year of Marquis Ai's rule, Lu assassinated their ruler Duke Yin. In the eighth year of Marquis Ai's rule, Jin invaded Xing Ting. Xing Ting conspired with Wu Gong of Quwo. In the ninth year, they attacked Jin along the Fen River and captured Marquis Ai. The Jin people then installed Xiao Zi, son of Marquis Ai, as their ruler, who became known as Lord Xiao Zi.

In the first year of Lord Xiao Zi's rule, Wu Gong of Quwo ordered Han Wan to kill the captive Marquis Ai of Jin. Quwo grew increasingly powerful. Jin had no means to counter it.

In the fourth year of Lord Xiao Zi's rule, Wu Gong of Quwo lured him with a summons and assassinated him. King Huan of Zhou ordered Guo Zhong to attack Wu Gong of Quwo. Wu Gong retreated into Quwo. They then installed Min, younger brother of Marquis Ai, as the Jin ruler.

In the fourth year of Duke Min of Jin's rule, Song seized Ji Zhong of Zheng and installed Tu as the ruler of Zheng. In the nineteenth year of Duke Min of Jin's rule, Guan Zhi Fu of Qi assassinated his ruler Duke Xiang.

In the twenty-eighth year of Duke Min of Jin's rule, Duke Huan of Qi began his era of hegemony. Wu Gong of Quwo attacked Duke Min of Jin and destroyed him. He completely bribed King Xi of Zhou with precious vessels. King Xi commanded Wu Gong of Quwo to become the ruler of Jin, granting him the rank of feudal lord. Thus he completely annexed all Jin territory and took possession of it.

æ›²æ²ƒæ­¦å…¬å·²å³ä½ä¸‰åä¸ƒå¹´çŸ£ï¼Œæ›´è™Ÿæ›°æ™‰æ­¦å…¬ã€‚ æ™‰æ­¦å…¬å§‹éƒ½æ™‰åœ‹ï¼Œå‰å³ä½æ›²æ²ƒï¼Œé€šå¹´ä¸‰åå…«å¹´ã€‚
Wu Gong of Quwo had already been on the throne for thirty-seven years. He changed his title to Duke Wu of Jin. Duke Wu of Jin first established his capital in the Jin state. Before his ascension, he had been at Quwo. In total, he ruled for thirty-eight years.

This Duke Wu was a great-grandson of the former Marquis Mu of Jin, and a grandson of Uncle Huan of Quwo. Uncle Huan was the first to be enfeoffed at Quwo. Duke Wu was the son of Zhuang Bo. From Uncle Huan's initial enfeoffment at Quwo until Duke Wu conquered Jin, it took altogether sixty-seven years, and he finally replaced Jin as a feudal lord. Duke Wu ruled over the unified Jin for two years, then died. Including his years at Quwo, he was on the throne for a total of thirty-nine years when he died. His son Gui Zhu ascended as Duke Xian.

In the first year of Duke Xian's rule, King Hui of Zhou's younger brother Sui attacked the king. King Hui fled and took refuge in the Li settlement of Zheng.

In the fifth year, he attacked the Lirong barbarians and captured Li Ji along with her younger brother. He loved and favored them both.

å…«å¹´ï¼Œå£«è’èªªå…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ•…æ™‰ä¹‹ç¾¤å…¬å­å¤šï¼Œä¸èª…ï¼Œäº‚ä¸”èµ·ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒä½¿ç›¡æ®ºè«¸å…¬å­ï¼Œè€ŒåŸèšéƒ½ä¹‹ï¼Œå‘½æ›°çµ³ï¼Œå§‹éƒ½çµ³ã€‚ ä¹å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰ç¾¤å…¬å­æ—¢äº¡å¥”è™¢ï¼Œè™¢ä»¥å…¶æ•…å†ä¼æ™‰ï¼Œå¼—å…‹ã€‚ åå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰æ¬²ä¼è™¢ï¼Œå£«è’æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸”å¾…å…¶äº‚ã€‚ã€
In the eighth year, Shi Wei persuaded the gong, saying: 'Formerly Jin's group of princes are many. If not executed, chaos is about to rise.' He then ordered the complete slaughter of all the princes, fortified the city as his capital, named it Jiang, and established Jiang as his capital city. In the ninth year, Jin's princes had already fled to Guo. Guo, taking advantage of this situation, attacked Jin again but failed to conquer it. In the tenth year, Jin desired to attack Guo. Shi Wei said: 'Moreover wait for their chaos.'

åäºŒå¹´ï¼Œé©ªå§¬ç”Ÿå¥šé½Šã€‚ ç»å…¬æœ‰æ„å»¢å¤ªå­ï¼Œä¹ƒæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ›²æ²ƒå¾å…ˆç¥–å®—å»Ÿæ‰€åœ¨ï¼Œè€Œè’²é‚Šç§¦ï¼Œå±ˆé‚Šç¿Ÿï¼Œä¸ä½¿è«¸å­å±…ä¹‹ï¼Œæˆ‘æ‡¼ç„‰ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ä½¿å¤ªå­ç”³ç”Ÿå±…æ›²æ²ƒï¼Œå…¬å­é‡è€³å±…è’²ï¼Œå…¬å­å¤·å¾å±…å±ˆã€‚ ç»å…¬èˆ‡é©ªå§¬å­å¥šé½Šå±…çµ³ã€‚ æ™‰åœ‹ä»¥æ­¤çŸ¥å¤ªå­ä¸ç«‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤ªå­ç”³ç”Ÿï¼Œå…¶æ¯é½Šæ¡“å…¬å¥³ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ›°é½Šå§œï¼Œæ—©æ­»ã€‚ ç”³ç”ŸåŒæ¯å¥³å¼Ÿç‚ºç§¦ç©†å…¬å¤«äººã€‚ é‡è€³æ¯ï¼Œç¿Ÿä¹‹ç‹æ°å¥³ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤·å¾æ¯ï¼Œé‡è€³æ¯å¥³å¼Ÿä¹Ÿã€‚ ç»å…¬å­å…«äººï¼Œè€Œå¤ªå­ç”³ç”Ÿã€é‡è€³ã€å¤·å¾çš†æœ‰è³¢è¡Œã€‚ åŠå¾—é©ªå§¬ï¼Œä¹ƒé æ­¤ä¸‰å­ã€‚
In the twelfth year, Li Ji gave birth to Xi Qi. Duke Xian had the intention to depose the crown prince. He then said: 'Qu Wo is where my first ancestor's ancestral temple is located. Pu borders Qin, Qu borders the Di. If I do not make the various sons reside there, I fear it.' He then stationed Crown Prince Shen Sheng at Quwo, Prince Chong Er at Pu, and Prince Yi Wu at Qu. Duke Xian resided at Jiang along with Li Ji's son Xi Qi. The state of Jin understood from this that the crown prince would not be established. Crown Prince Shen Sheng's mother was a daughter of Duke Huan of Qi, known as Qi Jiang. She died young. Shen Sheng's full younger sister became the consort of Duke Mu of Qin. Chong Er's mother was a woman from the Hu clan of the Di people. Yi Wu's mother was the younger sister of Chong Er's mother. Duke Xian had eight sons, and Crown Prince Shen Sheng, Chong Er, and Yi Wu all displayed virtuous conduct. After obtaining Li Ji, he began to distance himself from these three sons.

åå…­å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰ç»å…¬ä½œäºŒè»ã€‚ å…¬å°‡ä¸Šè»ï¼Œå¤ªå­ç”³ç”Ÿå°‡ä¸‹è»ï¼Œè¶™å¤™å¾¡æˆï¼Œç•¢è¬ç‚ºå³ï¼Œä¼æ»…éœï¼Œæ»…é­ï¼Œæ»…è€¿ã€‚ é‚„ï¼Œç‚ºå¤ªå­åŸæ›²æ²ƒï¼Œè³œè¶™å¤™è€¿ï¼Œè³œç•¢è¬é­ï¼Œä»¥ç‚ºå¤§å¤«ã€‚ å£«è’æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤ªå­ä¸å¾—ç«‹çŸ£ã€‚ åˆ†ä¹‹éƒ½åŸï¼Œè€Œä½ä»¥å¿ï¼Œå…ˆç‚ºä¹‹æ¥µï¼Œåˆå®‰å¾—ç«‹ï¼ ä¸å¦‚é€ƒä¹‹ï¼Œç„¡ä½¿ç½ªè‡³ã€‚ ç‚ºå³å¤ªä¼¯ï¼Œä¸äº¦å¯ä¹ï¼ŒçŒ¶æœ‰ä»¤åã€‚ã€ å¤ªå­ä¸å¾ã€‚ åœåƒæ›°ï¼šã€Œç•¢è¬ä¹‹å¾Œå¿…å¤§ã€‚ è¬ï¼Œç›ˆæ•¸ä¹Ÿï¼› é­ï¼Œå¤§åä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»¥æ˜¯å§‹è³ï¼Œå¤©é–‹ä¹‹çŸ£ã€‚ å¤©å­æ›°å…†æ°‘ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯æ›°è¬æ°‘ï¼Œä»Šå‘½ä¹‹å¤§ï¼Œä»¥å¾ç›ˆæ•¸ï¼Œå…¶å¿…æœ‰çœ¾ã€‚ã€ åˆï¼Œç•¢è¬åœä»•æ–¼æ™‰åœ‹ï¼Œé‡å±¯ä¹‹æ¯”ã€‚ è¾›å»–å ä¹‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå‰ã€‚ å±¯å›ºæ¯”å…¥ï¼Œå‰å­°å¤§ç„‰ã€‚ å…¶å¾Œå¿…è•ƒæ˜Œã€‚ã€
In the sixteenth year, Duke Xian of Jin organized two armies. The duke commanded the upper army. Crown Prince Shen Sheng commanded the lower army. Zhao Su drove the chariot. Bi Wan stood on the right. They attacked and destroyed Huo, destroyed Wei, and destroyed Geng. Upon returning, he fortified Quwo for the crown prince. He granted Geng to Zhao Su and Wei to Bi Wan, appointing them as grand officers. Shi Wei said: 'The crown prince will not be able to be established.' He divided him a capital city, and positioned him with qing rank. He first made him the pole. How again can he be established!' It would be better to flee. Do not let guilt befall you. To be like Wu Tai Boâ€”isn't that also permissible? You would still have a good name.' The crown prince refused to comply. Bu Yan said: 'Bi Wan's descendants must be great. Wan is a full number; Wei is an auspicious name. Beginning the rewards with thisâ€”heaven has blessed it. The tian zi is called myriad people, feudal lords are called ten thousand people. Now naming it great to follow the full numberâ€”it must have a multitude.' Initially, when Bi Wan divined about taking office in Jin, he received the hexagram Tun transforming into Bi. Xin Liao divined it and said: 'Auspicious. Tun is firm, and Bi enters. What greater auspiciousness could there be? His descendants must flourish and prosper.'

åä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰ä¾¯ä½¿å¤ªå­ç”³ç”Ÿä¼æ±å±±ã€‚ è£å…‹è««ç»å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤ªå­å¥‰å†¢ç¥€ç¤¾ç¨·ä¹‹ç²¢ç››ï¼Œä»¥æœå¤•è¦–å›è†³è€…ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ•…æ›°å†¢å­ã€‚ å›è¡Œå‰‡å®ˆï¼Œæœ‰å®ˆå‰‡å¾ï¼Œå¾æ›°æ’«è»ï¼Œå®ˆæ›°ç›£åœ‹ï¼Œå¤ä¹‹åˆ¶ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤«ç‡å¸«ï¼Œå°ˆè¡Œè¬€ä¹Ÿï¼› èª“è»æ—…ï¼Œå›èˆ‡åœ‹æ”¿ä¹‹æ‰€åœ–ä¹Ÿï¼šéå¤ªå­ä¹‹äº‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¸«åœ¨åˆ¶å‘½è€Œå·²ï¼Œç¨Ÿå‘½å‰‡ä¸å¨ï¼Œå°ˆå‘½å‰‡ä¸å­ï¼Œæ•…å›ä¹‹å—£é©ä¸å¯ä»¥å¸¥å¸«ã€‚ å›å¤±å…¶å®˜ï¼Œç‡å¸«ä¸å¨ï¼Œå°‡å®‰ç”¨ä¹‹ï¼Ÿã€ å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¯¡äººæœ‰å­ï¼ŒæœªçŸ¥å…¶å¤ªå­èª°ç«‹ã€‚ã€ è£å…‹ä¸å°è€Œé€€ï¼Œè¦‹å¤ªå­ã€‚ å¤ªå­æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾å…¶å»¢ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ è£å…‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤ªå­å‹‰ä¹‹ï¼ æ•™ä»¥è»æ—…ï¼Œä¸å…±æ˜¯æ‡¼ï¼Œä½•æ•…å»¢ä¹ï¼Ÿ ä¸”å­æ‡¼ä¸å­ï¼Œæ¯‹æ‡¼ä¸å¾—ç«‹ã€‚ ä¿®å·±è€Œä¸è²¬äººï¼Œå‰‡å…æ–¼é›£ã€‚ã€ å¤ªå­å¸¥å¸«ï¼Œå…¬è¡£ä¹‹åè¡£ï¼Œä½©ä¹‹é‡‘ç¦ã€‚ è£å…‹è¬ç—…ï¼Œä¸å¾å¤ªå­ã€‚ å¤ªå­é‚ä¼æ±å±±ã€‚
In the seventeenth year, Duke Xian of Jin sent Crown Prince Shen Sheng to attack Dongshan. Li Ke admonished Duke Xian, saying: 'The crown prince offers the ancestral sacrifices and the state's millet offerings to the altars. He oversees the lord's meals morning and evening. Therefore he is called the eldest son. When the ruler goes on campaign, a regent remains behind. With a regent, there is also a deputy. The deputy soothes the army. The regent oversees the state. This is the ancient system. Leading troops is monopolizing action and planning; Oathing the armiesâ€”what the lord and state governance plotted: it is not the crown prince's matter. The army exists only to execute commands. If receiving orders, it lacks authority. If monopolizing commands, it lacks filial piety. Therefore the ruler's legitimate heir cannot command troops. The lord loses his office. Leading troops is not awe-inspiring. How can it be used?' The gong said: 'I have sons. I do not know which crown prince to establish.' Li Ke made no response and withdrew. He went to see the crown prince. The crown prince said: 'Will I perhaps be deposed?' Li Ke said: 'Crown prince, strive!' He was taught with armies. He does not share this fear. Why would he be deposed? Moreover, fear only being unfilial. Do not fear failing to be established as heir. Cultivate yourself and do not blame others, then you will avoid calamity.' The crown prince commanded the troops. The duke clothed him in a mourning robe and girded him with a gold jue pendant. Li Ke pleaded illness and refused to accompany the crown prince. The crown prince then proceeded to attack Dongshan.

åä¹å¹´ï¼Œç»å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œå§‹å¾å…ˆå›èŠä¼¯ã€æ­¦å…¬ä¹‹èª…æ™‰äº‚ï¼Œè€Œè™¢å¸¸åŠ©æ™‰ä¼æˆ‘ï¼ŒåˆåŒ¿æ™‰äº¡å…¬å­ï¼Œæœç‚ºäº‚ã€‚ å¼—èª…ï¼Œå¾Œéºå­å­«æ†‚ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒä½¿è€æ¯ä»¥å±ˆç”¢ä¹‹ä¹˜å‡é“æ–¼è™ã€‚ è™å‡é“ï¼Œé‚ä¼è™¢ï¼Œå–å…¶ä¸‹é™½ä»¥æ­¸ã€‚
In the nineteenth year, Duke Xian said: 'From the beginning, my first lords Zhuang Bo and Wu Gong executed Jin's chaos, and Guo often helped Jin attack me. They again hid Jin's fled princes. Indeed they made rebellion. If not executed, later will leave descendants worry.' He then sent Xun Xi with Qu Chan's chariot team to request passage through Yu. Yu granted passage through its territory. He then attacked Guo, captured its Xiayang, and returned home.

ç»å…¬ç§è¬‚é©ªå§¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾æ¬²å»¢å¤ªå­ï¼Œä»¥å¥šé½Šä»£ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ é©ªå§¬æ³£æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤ªå­ä¹‹ç«‹ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯çš†å·²çŸ¥ä¹‹ï¼Œè€Œæ•¸å°‡å…µï¼Œç™¾å§“é™„ä¹‹ï¼ŒæŸ°ä½•ä»¥è³¤å¦¾ä¹‹æ•…å»¢é©ç«‹åº¶ï¼Ÿ å›å¿…è¡Œä¹‹ï¼Œå¦¾è‡ªæ®ºä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ é©ªå§¬è©³è­½å¤ªå­ï¼Œè€Œé™°ä»¤äººè­–æƒ¡å¤ªå­ï¼Œè€Œæ¬²ç«‹å…¶å­ã€‚
Duke Xian privately told Li Ji: 'I desire to depose the crown prince and replace him with Xi Qi.' Li Ji wept and said: 'The crown prince's establishmentâ€”all the feudal lords already know it. He frequently led troops. The common people are attached to him. How can you, for the sake of a lowly concubine, depose the proper heir and establish the concubine? If the lord must do it, the concubine will suicide.' Li Ji pretended to praise the crown prince, but secretly had people slander him and plot against him, all while scheming to establish her own son as heir.

In the twenty-first year, Li Ji told the crown prince: 'The lord dreamed he saw Qi Jiang. Crown prince, quickly sacrifice at Qu Wo and return the blessing to the lord.' The crown prince then performed sacrifices to his mother Qi Jiang at Quwo and presented the sacrificial meat to Duke Xian. Duke Xian had gone hunting at the time and left the sacrificial meat in the palace. Li Ji had her agents place poison in the sacrificial meat. Two days later, Duke Xian returned from hunting. The cook presented the sacrificial meat to him. Duke Xian wanted to taste it. Li Ji stopped him from the side, saying: 'The meat comes from far away. You should test it.' He sacrificed to the earth, and the earth rose up; He gave it to a dog, and the dog died; He gave some to a junior official, who died after eating it. Li Ji wept and said: 'How cruel the crown prince is! He desires to assassinate and replace even his own father. What about others? Moreover, the lord is old, a person of morning and evening. He once cannot wait and desires to assassinate him!' She told Duke Xian: 'The reason the crown prince does this is nothing more than because of me and Xi Qi. I wish you mother and son would flee to another state. If we commit suicide early, we won't be letting mother and son be butchered by the crown prince for nothing. At the beginning when the lord desired to depose him, I still resented it; Until now, I especially feel I have lost myself in this.' The crown prince heard about this and fled to Xincheng. Duke Xian was furious and had his tutor Du Yuankuan executed. Someone told the crown prince: 'The one who made this medicine was Li Ji. Why doesn't the crown prince explain and clarify it himself?' The crown prince said: 'My lord is old. Without Li Ji, his sleep is not peaceful, his eating is not sweet. If I explain this, the duke will be angry about it. It cannot be done.' Someone told the crown prince: 'You can flee to another state.' The crown prince said: 'To leave carrying this evil nameâ€”who among people would accept me? I will commit suicide.' In the twelfth month, on the day Wu Shen, Shen Sheng committed suicide at Xincheng.

At this time, Chong Er and Yi Wu came to pay court to their father. Someone told Li Ji: 'The two princes resent that Li Ji slandered and killed the crown prince.' Li Ji feared, and therefore slandered the two princes: 'The two princes knew about Shen Sheng's poisoned meat.' The two brothers heard about it and became fearful. Chong Er fled to Pu, Yi Wu fled to Qu, each defending their cities and preparing for their own protection. Initially, Duke Xian had Shi Wei build fortified cities for his two sons at Pu and Qu, but Shi Wei did not complete the work. Yi Wu reported this to his father, who became angry with Shi Wei. Shi Wei apologized and said: 'Border cities have few bandits. Why use them?' He retreated and sang: 'Fox fur robe bushy, one state three gongâ€”who should I follow!' Shi Wei finally completed the fortifications. When Shen Sheng died, the two brothers also returned to their fortified cities to defend them.

In the twenty-second year, Duke Xian became furious that his two sons had left without taking leave of him. Indeed they were plotting against him. He sent troops to attack Pu. An eunuch in Pu named Bo Di ordered Chong Er to commit suicide immediately. Chong Er leaped over the wall. The eunuch pursued him and slashed at his robe sleeve. Chong Er then fled to the Di people. He sent forces to attack Qu. The defenders of Qu held firm, and the city could not be taken.

That same year, Jin once again requested passage through Yu territory to attack Guo. Yu's grand officer Gong Zhi Qi admonished the Yu lord: 'Jin cannot be granted passage. This is about to extinguish Yu.' The Yu lord said: 'Jin and I have the same surname. It is not proper for them to attack me.' Gong Zhi Qi said: 'Tai Bo and Yu Zhong were Tai Wang's sons. Tai Bo fled away, therefore he did not succeed. Guo Zhong and Guo Shu were sons of Wang Ji. They served as ministers to King Wen. Records of their meritorious deeds are preserved in the royal archives and stored in the covenant treasury. They will extinguish Guo. Why cherish Yu? Moreover, can Yu's kinship be closer than the Huan and Zhuang clans? What crime had the clans of Huan and Zhuang committed? Yet they were completely destroyed. Yu and Guo are like lips and teeth. If the lips are gone, the teeth will be cold.' The Duke of Yu would not heed the warning and granted permission to Jin. Gong Zhiqi left Yu along with his entire clan. That winter, Jin destroyed Guo. Duke Chou of Guo fled to the Zhou capital. On the return, they launched a surprise attack and destroyed Yu, taking the Duke of Yu and his minister Baili Xi as attendants for Qin Mu Ji, while preserving Yu's ancestral sacrifices. Xun Xi led the previously left horses produced by Yu and Qu and presented them to Duke Xian. Duke Xian laughed and said: 'The horses are then my horses, but their teeth are also old!'

äºŒåä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œç»å…¬é‚ç™¼è³ˆè¯ç­‰ä¼å±ˆï¼Œå±ˆæ½°ã€‚ å¤·å¾å°‡å¥”ç¿Ÿã€‚ å†€èŠ®æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å¯ï¼Œé‡è€³å·²åœ¨çŸ£ï¼Œä»Šå¾€ï¼Œæ™‰å¿…ç§»å…µä¼ç¿Ÿï¼Œç¿Ÿç•æ™‰ï¼Œç¦ä¸”åŠã€‚ ä¸å¦‚èµ°æ¢ï¼Œæ¢è¿‘æ–¼ç§¦ï¼Œç§¦å½Šï¼Œå¾å›ç™¾æ­²å¾Œå¯ä»¥æ±‚å…¥ç„‰ã€‚ã€ é‚å¥”æ¢ã€‚ äºŒåäº”å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰ä¼ç¿Ÿï¼Œç¿Ÿä»¥é‡è€³æ•…ï¼Œäº¦æ“Šæ™‰æ–¼é½§æ¡‘ï¼Œæ™‰å…µè§£è€Œå»ã€‚
In the twenty-third year, Duke Xian sent Jia Hua and others to attack Qu. The city fell. Yi Wu was about to flee to the Di people. Ji Rui said: 'Not permissible. Chong Er is already there. Li Ji's younger brother bore Dao Zi.

In summer of the twenty-sixth year, Duke Huan of Qi convened a great assembly of the feudal lords at Kuiqiu. Duke Xian of Jin fell ill. He set out later but had not yet arrived when he encountered Kong, the Zhou steward. Steward Kong said: 'Duke Huan of Qi is increasingly arrogant. He does not attend to virtue but attends to distant strategies. The feudal lords are not content. My lord, do not assemble. What can Jin do?' Duke Xian also fell ill and returned home again. His illness became severe. He then told Xun Xi: 'I am making Xi Qi my successor. He is young. The various ministers will not submit. I fear chaos will rise. Can you establish him?' Xun Xi said: 'I can.' Duke Xian said: 'What will serve as verification?' He replied: 'Make the dead revive, the living not ashamedâ€”make this the verification.' Thereupon they entrusted Xi Qi to Xun Xi. Xun Xi became prime minister and took charge of state affairs. In the ninth month of autumn, Duke Xian died. Li Ke and Pi Zheng desired to bring in Chong Er. With the three princes' followers they made chaos. They told Xun Xi: 'Three resentments will rise. Qin and Jin will help them. What will you do?' Xun Xi said: 'I cannot betray the former lord's words.' In the tenth month, Li Ke assassinated Xi Qi at the mourning pavilion before Duke Xian had even been buried. Xun Xi was prepared to die for his duty. Someone suggested it would be better to establish Xi Qi's younger brother Dao Zi and act as his tutor. Xun Xi established Dao Zi and buried Duke Xian. In the eleventh month, Li Ke assassinated Dao Zi in the court. Xun Xi died in loyalty to his charge. The gentleman said: 'As the Shi says: 'A white gui's blemish can still be ground away. This words' blemish cannot be done.' Is this speaking of Xun Xi! He did not betray his words.' Initially, when Duke Xian was about to attack the Li Rong, the divination said 'teeth and fangs will become calamity'. When he defeated the Lirong and captured Li Ji, he fell in love with her. In the end, this brought chaos to Jin.

Li Ke and his faction had already assassinated Xi Qi and Dao Zi. They sent envoys to welcome Prince Chong Er from the Di and install him as ruler. Chong Er declined, saying: 'I carried my father's command and fled. My father died and I was not able to cultivate the ritual of a filial son and attend the mourning. How dare Chong Er enter! The grand officers should change and establish another son.' They returned and reported to Li Ke. Li Ke sent them to welcome Yi Wu from Liang. Yi Wu desired to go. Lu Sheng and Xi Rui said: 'There are still princes inside who can be established, yet we seek outside. It is difficult to trust. The plan is not of Qin. Helping a strong state's might to enterâ€”we fear danger.' They then made Xi Rui thickly bribe Qin, agreeing: 'If we obtain entry, please give Jin's He Xi land to Qin.' They also sent Li Ke a letter: 'If truly established, please then enfeoff your son at Fen Yang's city.' Duke Mu of Qin then dispatched troops to escort Yi Wu to Jin. Duke Huan of Qi heard of Jin's internal chaos and also led the feudal lords to Jin. The Qin troops escorting Yi Wu also arrived in Jin. Qi then had Xi Peng meet with Qin to jointly install Yi Wu as ruler of Jin, who became Duke Hui. Duke Huan of Qi reached Gaoliang in Jin territory and then returned home.

In Duke Hui Yi Wu's first year, he made Pi Zheng thank Qin, saying: 'At the beginning Yi Wu promised the lord He Xi land. Now fortunately I obtain entry and establishment. The ministers said: 'The land is the former lord's land. The lord fled outsideâ€”how can he monopolize and promise it to Qin?' I contended for it but was not able to obtain it, therefore I thank Qin.' He also refused to grant Li Ke the city of Fenyang and stripped him of his authority. In the fourth month, King Xiang of Zhou sent the Duke of Zhou, Ji Fu, to meet with ministers from Qi and Qin and jointly perform the investiture ceremonies for Duke Hui of Jin. Duke Hui, fearing that Li Ke might rebel while Chong Er remained in exile, ordered Li Ke executed. He told him: 'Without Li Zi, I would not have been able to establish myself. Although this is so, you also killed two lords and one grand officer. For your lordâ€”is this not also difficult?' Li Ke replied: 'If not having something deposed, how can the lord rise? Desiring to execute himâ€”does he have no words?' He then spoke on behalf of this! This minister has heard the command.' He then fell upon his sword and died. Pi Zheng's envoy sent to thank Qin had not yet returned, so he escaped the purge.

The ruler of Jin reburied Crown Prince Gong Shen Sheng. In autumn, when Hu Tu was going down to the state, he met Shen Sheng. Shen Sheng rode with him and told him: 'Yi Wu lacks ritual. I obtained a request from the Emperor. I will give Jin to Qin. Qin will sacrifice to me.' Hu Tu replied: 'This minister has heard that spirits do not accept offerings that are not from their ancestral temple. My lord, will your sacrifices not be cut off? My lord should plan for it.' Shen Sheng said: 'Very well. I will again request the Emperor. After ten days, on the west side of Xin Cheng, there will be a shaman who sees me there.' He promised to do so, and then disappeared. When the time came and he went, he was seen again. Shen Sheng told him: 'The Emperor has permitted punishment of the guilty. It will end at Han.' The child then sang: 'Crown Prince Gong has been reburied. After fourteen years, Jin will also not prosper. Prosperity will then be in the elder brother.'

Pi Zheng's envoy to Qin, hearing that Li Ke was executed, then persuaded Qin Mu Gong: 'Lu Sheng, Xi Cheng, and Ji Rui are truly not obedient. They then executed Pi Zheng and Li Ke, along with seven high-ranking ministers who were Pi Zheng's faction. Pi Zheng's son Bao fled to Qin and urged an attack on Jin, but Duke Mu refused to listen.

Duke Hui's enthronement promised Qin double the land and Li Ke's head. He executed seven high ministers. The people of the state did not support him. In the second year, the Zhou court sent the Duke of Shao, Guo, to conduct the investiture ceremonies for Duke Hui of Jin. Duke Hui behaved arrogantly. The Duke of Shao rebuked him.

In the fourth year, Jin suffered famine and begged Qin for grain. Mu Gong asked Bai Li Xi. Bai Li Xi said: 'Heaven's calamities circulate. States alternately have them. Saving calamities and relieving neighbors is the way of the state. Give it to them.' Pi Zheng's son Bao said: 'Attack them.' Mu Gong said: 'Their lord is evil. In the fifth year, Qin suffered famine and requested grain from Jin. The Jin lord consulted about it. Qing Zheng said: 'We obtained establishment through Qin, then doubled their land agreement. When Jin suffered famine Qin lent to us. Now when Qin suffers famine and requests grain, what doubt is there in giving to them? And plot against them!' Guo She said: 'In the previous year, heaven granted Jin to Qin. Qin did not know to take it and lent to us. Today heaven grants Qin to Jin. How can Jin oppose heaven? We should then attack them.' Duke Hui followed Guo She's advice. He refused to give grain to Qin and instead sent troops to attack Qin. Qin was furious and also sent troops to attack Jin.

In spring of the sixth year, Duke Mu of Qin led troops to attack Jin. Duke Hui of Jin told Qing Zheng: 'The Qin army has penetrated deeply. What shall we do?' Zheng said: 'Qin brought in the lord, and the lord doubled their bribe; When Jin suffered famine Qin transported grain, when Qin suffered famine Jin doubled it, then desired to take advantage of their famine to attack themâ€”is their deep penetration not also proper!' Jin divined about the chariot driver and right-hand man. Qing Zheng received entirely auspicious omens. The gong said: 'Zheng is not filial.' He then ordered Bu Yang to drive the chariot again, with his family slave Tu as the right-hand man, and advanced the troops. On the day Renxu in the ninth month, Duke Mu of Qin and Duke Hui of Jin clashed in battle at Hanyuan. Duke Hui's horse stumbled and refused to move. Qin troops arrived. The duke was in dire straits and summoned Qing Zheng to drive the chariot. Zheng said: 'Did not use divination. Is defeat not also proper!' Qing Zheng then fled. He then ordered Liang Youmi to drive the chariot, with Guo She as the right-hand man, and pursued Duke Mu of Qin. Duke Mu's warriors bravely counterattacked and defeated the Jin army. The Jin forces were routed. In the confusion, they lost Duke Mu of Qin, but captured Duke Hui of Jin instead and returned with him. Qin intended to sacrifice him to the Supreme Deity. The Duke of Jin's elder sister was Duke Mu's consort. She wept bitterly while wearing mourning garments. The gong said: 'I obtained the Jin hou and was going to take him as joy. Now it is like this. Moreover, I heard that Ji Zi saw Tang Shu's initial enfeoffment and said 'his descendants must greatly.' How can Jin be extinguished!' He then formed an alliance with the Duke of Jin at Wangcheng and allowed him to return home. The Jin hou also made Lu Sheng and others report to the state people: 'Though I obtain return, I have no face to see the altars. Divine a day to establish Zi Yu.' When the people of Jin heard the news, they all wept. Qin Mu Gong asked Lu Sheng: 'Is the Jin state harmonious?' He replied: 'Not harmonious. The small people fear losing their lord and kin. They do not dread establishing Zi Yu, saying 'We must avenge enmity. We would rather serve the Rong and Di.' Their gentlemen love the lord and know their guilt. They await Qin's command, saying 'We must repay virtue.' Because of these two reasons, not harmonious.' Thereupon Duke Mu of Qin housed Duke Hui of Jin once more and bestowed upon him seven sacrificial animals. In the eleventh month, they sent the Duke of Jin home. Upon returning to Jin, the duke executed Qing Zheng and reformed the administration. They consulted: 'Chong Er is outside. Many feudal lords would profit by bringing him in.' He wanted to send assassins to kill Chong Er among the Di people. Chong Er heard about this and fled to Qi.

In the eighth year, he sent Crown Prince Yu as a hostage to Qin. Initially, while Duke Hui was in exile in Liang, the Marquis of Liang gave him his daughter in marriage. She bore him one son and one daughter. The Marquis of Liang consulted the oracle about them. The son would serve as a minister to others, the daughter as a concubine to others. Therefore he named the son Yu and the daughter Concubine.

In the tenth year, Qin destroyed Liang. Liang Bo liked earthworks. He managed city moats. The people's strength was exhausted and resentful. Their multitudes several times mutually alarmed themselves, saying 'Qin bandits have arrived.' The people were fearful and bewildered. Qin finally extinguished it.

åä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰æƒ å…¬ç—…ï¼Œå…§æœ‰æ•¸å­ã€‚ å¤ªå­åœ‰æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾æ¯å®¶åœ¨æ¢ï¼Œæ¢ä»Šç§¦æ»…ä¹‹ï¼Œæˆ‘å¤–è¼•æ–¼ç§¦è€Œå…§ç„¡æ´æ–¼åœ‹ã€‚ å›å³ä¸èµ·ï¼Œç—…å¤§å¤«è¼•ï¼Œæ›´ç«‹ä»–å…¬å­ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒè¬€èˆ‡å…¶å¦»ä¿±äº¡æ­¸ã€‚ ç§¦å¥³æ›°ï¼šã€Œå­ä¸€åœ‹å¤ªå­ï¼Œè¾±åœ¨æ­¤ã€‚ ç§¦ä½¿å©¢å­ä¾ï¼Œä»¥å›ºå­ä¹‹å¿ƒã€‚ å­äº¡çŸ£ï¼Œæˆ‘ä¸å¾å­ï¼Œäº¦ä¸æ•¢è¨€ã€‚ã€ å­åœ‰é‚äº¡æ­¸æ™‰ã€‚ åå››å¹´ä¹æœˆï¼Œæƒ å…¬å’ï¼Œå¤ªå­åœ‰ç«‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ‡·å…¬ã€‚
In the thirteenth year, Duke Hui of Jin fell ill. He had several sons. Crown Prince Yu said: 'My mother's family is in Liang. Qin has now extinguished Liang. I am light to Qin outside and have no aid in the state inside. If the lord does not rise, the ill grand officers are light. Change and establish another prince.' He then conspired with his wife to flee together and return home. The Qin woman said: 'You are one state's crown prince, humiliated here. Qin sent a maidservant to attend you, to reassure your heart. You have fled. I will not follow you, nor dare I speak.' Zi Yu then fled back to Jin. In the ninth month of the fourteenth year, Duke Hui died. Crown Prince Yu ascended the throne, becoming Duke Huai.

å­åœ‰ä¹‹äº¡ï¼Œç§¦æ€¨ä¹‹ï¼Œä¹ƒæ±‚å…¬å­é‡è€³ï¼Œæ¬²å…§ä¹‹ã€‚ å­åœ‰ä¹‹ç«‹ï¼Œç•ç§¦ä¹‹ä¼ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¹ƒä»¤åœ‹ä¸­è«¸å¾é‡è€³äº¡è€…èˆ‡æœŸï¼ŒæœŸç›¡ä¸åˆ°è€…ç›¡æ»…å…¶å®¶ã€‚ ç‹çªä¹‹å­æ¯›åŠåƒå¾é‡è€³åœ¨ç§¦ï¼Œå¼—è‚¯å¬ã€‚ æ‡·å…¬æ€’ï¼Œå›šç‹çªã€‚ çªæ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£å­äº‹é‡è€³æœ‰å¹´æ•¸çŸ£ï¼Œä»Šå¬ä¹‹ï¼Œæ˜¯æ•™ä¹‹åå›ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä½•ä»¥æ•™ä¹‹ï¼Ÿã€ æ‡·å…¬å’æ®ºç‹çªã€‚ ç§¦ç¹†å…¬ä¹ƒç™¼å…µé€å…§é‡è€³ï¼Œä½¿äººå‘Šæ¬’ã€éƒ¤ä¹‹é»¨ç‚ºå…§æ‡‰ï¼Œæ®ºæ‡·å…¬æ–¼é«˜æ¢ï¼Œå…¥é‡è€³ã€‚ é‡è€³ç«‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ–‡å…¬ã€‚
Zi Yu's flight angered Qin, so they sought out Prince Chong Er, desiring to install him as ruler. Zi Yu's enthronement was motivated by fear of a Qin invasion. He then ordered all those in the state who had followed Chong Er into exile to report by a deadline. Those who failed to appear would have their entire families executed. Hu Tu's sons Mao and Yan were with Chong Er in Qin and refused to answer the summons. Duke Huai was furious and imprisoned Hu Tu. Tu said: 'The minister's sons have served Chong Er for several years. Now summoning them teaches them to oppose their lord. How to teach them?' Duke Huai eventually had Hu Tu executed. Duke Mu of Qin then dispatched troops to escort Chong Er back. He instructed the factions of Luan and Xi to provide internal support, assassinated Duke Huai at Gaoliang, and installed Chong Er as ruler. Chong Er ascended the throne, becoming Duke Wen.

æ™‰æ–‡å…¬é‡è€³ï¼Œæ™‰ç»å…¬ä¹‹å­ä¹Ÿã€‚ è‡ªå°‘å¥½å£«ï¼Œå¹´åä¸ƒï¼Œæœ‰è³¢å£«äº”äººï¼šæ›°è¶™è¡°ï¼› ç‹åƒå’çŠ¯ï¼Œæ–‡å…¬èˆ…ä¹Ÿï¼› è³ˆä½—ï¼› å…ˆè»«ï¼› é­æ­¦å­ã€‚ è‡ªç»å…¬ç‚ºå¤ªå­æ™‚ï¼Œé‡è€³å›ºå·²æˆäººçŸ£ã€‚ ç»å…¬å³ä½ï¼Œé‡è€³å¹´äºŒåä¸€ã€‚ ç»å…¬åä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œä»¥é©ªå§¬æ•…ï¼Œé‡è€³å‚™è’²åŸå®ˆç§¦ã€‚ ç»å…¬äºŒåä¸€å¹´ï¼Œç»å…¬æ®ºå¤ªå­ç”³ç”Ÿï¼Œé©ªå§¬è®’ä¹‹ï¼Œæï¼Œä¸è¾­ç»å…¬è€Œå®ˆè’²åŸã€‚ ç»å…¬äºŒåäºŒå¹´ï¼Œç»å…¬ä½¿å®¦è€…å±¥é®è¶£æ®ºé‡è€³ã€‚ é‡è€³è¸°å£ï¼Œå®¦è€…é€æ–¬å…¶è¡£è¢ªã€‚ é‡è€³é‚å¥”ç‹„ã€‚ ç‹„ï¼Œå…¶æ¯åœ‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ˜¯æ™‚é‡è€³å¹´å››åä¸‰ã€‚ å¾æ­¤äº”å£«ï¼Œå…¶é¤˜ä¸åè€…æ•¸åäººï¼Œè‡³ç‹„ã€‚
Duke Wen of Jin, Chong Er, was a son of Duke Xian of Jin. From young he liked scholars. At age seventeen, he had five worthy scholars: Zhao Cui; Hu Yan Jiu Fan, Duke Wen's maternal uncle; Jia Tuo; Xian Zhen; Wei Wu Zi. Even when Duke Xian was still crown prince, Chong Er had already come of age. When Duke Xian ascended the throne, Chong Er was twenty-one years old. In Duke Xian's thirteenth year, because of Li Ji's influence, Chong Er fortified Pu city to defend against Qin. In Duke Xian's twenty-first year, Duke Xian had Crown Prince Shen Sheng executed after Li Ji slandered him. Chong Er became fearful and, without taking leave of Duke Xian, fortified himself in Pu city. In Duke Xian's twenty-second year, Duke Xian sent the eunuch Ludi to hasten Chong Er's assassination. Chong Er leaped over the wall. The eunuch pursued him and slashed at his robe sleeve. Chong Er then fled to the Di people. The Di were his mother's people. At this time, Chong Er was forty-three years old. These five scholars accompanied him. Several dozen others whose names are not recorded also reached the Di.

ç‹„ä¼å’å¦‚ï¼Œå¾—äºŒå¥³ï¼šä»¥é•·å¥³å¦»é‡è€³ï¼Œç”Ÿä¼¯é¯ˆã€å”åŠ‰ï¼› ä»¥å°‘å¥³å¦»è¶™è¡°ï¼Œç”Ÿç›¾ã€‚ å±…ç‹„äº”æ­²è€Œæ™‰ç»å…¬å’ï¼Œè£å…‹å·²æ®ºå¥šé½Šã€æ‚¼å­ï¼Œä¹ƒä½¿äººè¿ï¼Œæ¬²ç«‹é‡è€³ã€‚ é‡è€³ç•æ®ºï¼Œå› å›ºè¬ï¼Œä¸æ•¢å…¥ã€‚ å·²è€Œæ™‰æ›´è¿å…¶å¼Ÿå¤·å¾ç«‹ä¹‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæƒ å…¬ã€‚ æƒ å…¬ä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œç•é‡è€³ï¼Œä¹ƒä½¿å®¦è€…å±¥é®èˆ‡å£¯å£«æ¬²æ®ºé‡è€³ã€‚ é‡è€³èä¹‹ï¼Œä¹ƒè¬€è¶™è¡°ç­‰æ›°ï¼šã€Œå§‹å¾å¥”ç‹„ï¼Œéä»¥ç‚ºå¯ç”¨èˆ‡ï¼Œä»¥è¿‘æ˜“é€šï¼Œæ•…ä¸”ä¼‘è¶³ã€‚ ä¼‘è¶³ä¹…çŸ£ï¼Œå›ºé¡˜å¾™ä¹‹å¤§åœ‹ã€‚ å¤«é½Šæ¡“å…¬å¥½å–„ï¼Œå¿—åœ¨éœ¸ç‹ï¼Œæ”¶æ¤è«¸ä¾¯ã€‚ ä»Šèç®¡ä»²ã€éš°æœ‹æ­»ï¼Œæ­¤äº¦æ¬²å¾—è³¢ä½ï¼Œç›å¾€ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ–¼æ˜¯é‚è¡Œã€‚ é‡è€³è¬‚å…¶å¦»æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾…æˆ‘äºŒåäº”å¹´ä¸ä¾†ï¼Œä¹ƒå«ã€‚ã€ å…¶å¦»ç¬‘æ›°ï¼šã€ŒçŠäºŒåäº”å¹´ï¼Œå¾å†¢ä¸ŠæŸå¤§çŸ£ã€‚ é›–ç„¶ï¼Œå¦¾å¾…å­ã€‚ã€ é‡è€³å±…ç‹„å‡¡åäºŒå¹´è€Œå»ã€‚
Di attacked Jiu Ru and obtained two women. They married the elder daughter to Chong Er. She gave birth to Bo Tao and Shu Liu; They gave their younger daughter in marriage to Zhao Cui. She bore him Dun. He had lived among the Di for five years when Duke Xian of Jin died. Li Ke had already assassinated Xi Qi and Dao Zi. He then sent envoys to welcome Chong Er, intending to install him as ruler. Chong Er feared assassination and therefore firmly declined the invitation. He dared not return. Soon after, Jin welcomed his younger brother Yi Wu and installed him as ruler, who became Duke Hui. In Duke Hui's seventh year, fearing Chong Er's growing influence, he sent the eunuch Ludi along with warriors to assassinate Chong Er. Chong Er heard of it and then consulted Zhao Cui and others: 'At the beginning I fled to Di, not because I thought it usable with them, but because it was near and easy to communicate with, so I temporarily rested my feet. I have rested long enough. I firmly wish to move to a great state. Duke Huan of Qi was fond of worthy men. His ambition was to become hegemon king. He gathered and aided the feudal lords. Now I hear Guan Zhong and Xi Peng have died. He also desires to obtain worthy assistants. Why not go?' Thereupon he set out. Chong Er told his wife: 'Wait for me twenty-five years. If I do not come, then marry.' His wife laughed and said: 'After plowing for twenty-five years, the cypress on my tomb will be big.' Although that is so, this concubine will wait for you.' Chong Er lived among the Di for a total of twelve years before departing.

éè¡›ï¼Œè¡›æ–‡å…¬ä¸ç¦®ã€‚ å»ï¼Œéäº”é¹¿ï¼Œé¥‘è€Œå¾é‡äººä¹é£Ÿï¼Œé‡äººç››åœŸå™¨ä¸­é€²ä¹‹ã€‚ é‡è€³æ€’ã€‚ è¶™è¡°æ›°ï¼šã€ŒåœŸè€…ï¼Œæœ‰åœŸä¹Ÿï¼Œå›å…¶æ‹œå—ä¹‹ã€‚ã€
He passed through Wei. Duke Wen of Wei showed him no courtesy. He departed and passed through Wulu. Famished, he begged food from a peasant. The peasant filled an earthen bowl with dirt and presented it to him. Chong Er became furious. Zhao Cui said: 'Earth means having land. My lord should bow and receive it.'

è‡³é½Šï¼Œé½Šæ¡“å…¬åšç¦®ï¼Œè€Œä»¥å®—å¥³å¦»ä¹‹ï¼Œæœ‰é¦¬äºŒåä¹˜ï¼Œé‡è€³å®‰ä¹‹ã€‚ é‡è€³è‡³é½ŠäºŒæ­²è€Œæ¡“å…¬å’ï¼Œæœƒè±åˆ€ç­‰ç‚ºå…§äº‚ï¼Œé½Šå­å…¬ä¹‹ç«‹ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯å…µæ•¸è‡³ã€‚ ç•™é½Šå‡¡äº”æ­²ã€‚ é‡è€³æ„›é½Šå¥³ï¼Œæ¯‹å»å¿ƒã€‚ è¶™è¡°ã€å’çŠ¯ä¹ƒæ–¼æ¡‘ä¸‹è¬€è¡Œã€‚ é½Šå¥³ä¾è€…åœ¨æ¡‘ä¸Šèä¹‹ï¼Œä»¥å‘Šå…¶ä¸»ã€‚ å…¶ä¸»ä¹ƒæ®ºä¾è€…ï¼Œå‹¸é‡è€³è¶£è¡Œã€‚ é‡è€³æ›°ï¼šã€Œäººç”Ÿå®‰æ¨‚ï¼Œå­°çŸ¥å…¶ä»–ï¼ å¿…æ­»æ–¼æ­¤ï¼Œä¸èƒ½å»ã€‚ã€ é½Šå¥³æ›°ï¼šã€Œå­ä¸€åœ‹å…¬å­ï¼Œçª®è€Œä¾†æ­¤ï¼Œæ•¸å£«è€…ä»¥å­ç‚ºå‘½ã€‚ å­ä¸ç–¾ååœ‹ï¼Œå ±å‹è‡£ï¼Œè€Œæ‡·å¥³å¾·ï¼Œç«Šç‚ºå­ç¾ä¹‹ã€‚ ä¸”ä¸æ±‚ï¼Œä½•æ™‚å¾—åŠŸï¼Ÿã€ ä¹ƒèˆ‡è¶™è¡°ç­‰è¬€ï¼Œé†‰é‡è€³ï¼Œè¼‰ä»¥è¡Œã€‚ è¡Œé è€Œè¦ºï¼Œé‡è€³å¤§æ€’ï¼Œå¼•æˆˆæ¬²æ®ºå’çŠ¯ã€‚ å’çŠ¯æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ®ºè‡£æˆå­ï¼Œåƒä¹‹é¡˜ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ é‡è€³æ›°ï¼šã€Œäº‹ä¸æˆï¼Œæˆ‘é£Ÿèˆ…æ°ä¹‹è‚‰ã€‚ã€ å’çŠ¯æ›°ï¼šã€Œäº‹ä¸æˆï¼ŒçŠ¯è‚‰è…¥è‡Šï¼Œä½•è¶³é£Ÿï¼ã€ ä¹ƒæ­¢ï¼Œé‚è¡Œã€‚
He arrived in Qi. Duke Huan of Qi treated him with great courtesy and gave him a daughter of the royal clan in marriage. He was provided with twenty chariot teams. Chong Er settled comfortably. Chong Er had been in Qi for two years when Duke Huan died. At that time, Shudao and others created internal disorder. During Duke Xiao of Qi's succession, the troops of feudal lords arrived several times. He remained in Qi for a total of five years. Chong Er loved his Qi wife and had no desire to leave. Zhao Cui and Jiufan then plotted their departure beneath the mulberry tree. The Qi woman's attendant, who was up in the mulberry tree, heard their conversation and informed her mistress. Her mistress then killed the attendant and urged Chong Er to depart immediately. Chong Er said: 'Human life is peaceful and joyful. Who knows anything else! I must die here. I cannot leave.' The Qi woman said: 'You are one state's prince. You came here in poverty. Several scholars take you as their fate. If you do not quickly return to your state to reward your loyal ministers, but instead cling to a woman's affection, I am secretly ashamed for you. Moreover, if you do not seek it, when will you obtain merit?' She then conspired with Zhao Cui and the others. They got Chong Er drunk and carried him away in a cart. They had gone some distance when he awoke. Chong Er was furious and drew his spear, intending to kill Jiufan. Jiu Fan said: 'Kill this minister to complete youâ€”that is Yan's wish.' Chong Er said: 'If the matter does not succeed, I will eat my maternal uncle's clan's flesh.' Jiu Fan said: 'If the matter does not succeed, Fan's flesh will be rank and rancid. What is sufficient to eat!' He then desisted and they continued on their way.

Duke Huai's former ministers LÃ¼ Sheng and Xi Rui had never supported Duke Wen. Duke Wen reformed the administration and bestowed benefits upon the common people. He rewarded those who had followed him into exile and his meritorious ministers. Upper and lower mutually deceive each other. It is difficult to dwell with them!' His mother said: 'Why not also seek it? With death, who would resent?' In spring of the second year, Qin troops were positioned on the Yellow River, poised to enter the Zhou capital. In spring of the fifth year, Duke Wen of Jin wanted to attack Cao. He requested passage through Wei, but the Wei people refused. In the seventh year, Duke Wen of Jin and Duke Mu of Qin jointly besieged Zheng, because of its discourtesy to Duke Wen during his exile, and because Zheng had assisted Chu at the time of Chengpu. They besieged Zheng, desiring to capture Shu Zhan. Shu Zhan heard about this and committed suicide. Zheng presented Shu Zhan's corpse to Jin as proof. Jin said: 'We must obtain the Zheng lord and satisfy our hearts.' Zheng feared, and then secretly commanded an envoy to tell Qin Mu Gong: 'Perishing Zheng enriches Jin. At Jin it is obtained, but Qin has not yet benefited. Why doesn't the lord relieve Zheng and obtain to become eastern road allies?' The Duke of Qin was satisfied and withdrew his troops. Jin also withdrew its troops.

In winter of the ninth year, Duke Wen of Jin died, and his son Duke Xiang Huan ascended the throne. That same year, the Marquis of Zheng also died.

Some people in Zheng betrayed their country by selling information to Qin, and Duke Mu of Qin dispatched troops to launch a surprise attack on Zheng. In the twelfth month, Qin troops passed through our suburbs. In spring of Duke Xiang's first year, the Qin army passed through Zhou territory without showing proper respect, and Wang Sunman rebuked them. The troops reached Hua. The Zheng merchant Xian Gao, who was traveling to Zhou to trade, encountered them and presented twelve oxen to welcome the Qin army. The Qin army was alarmed and turned back, destroying Hua on the way and then departing.

Jin Xian Zhen said: 'The Qin lord did not use Jian Shu, turning against the hearts of their multitude. This can be attacked.' Luan Zhi said: 'We have not yet repaid our former lord's favor to Qin. Attacking them is not permissible.' Xian Zhen said: 'Qin insulted our orphan, attacked our same surname. What virtue's repayment is this?' They then attacked them. Duke Xiang wore mourning garments dyed black. In the fourth month, they defeated the Qin army at Xiao and captured the three Qin generals Meng Mingshi, Xi Qishu, and Bai Yibing. They then used black-dyed garments to bury Duke Wen. Wen Gong's lady, a Qin woman, told Xiang Gong: 'Qin desires to obtain their three generals and execute them.' The duke agreed and released them. Xian Zhen heard it and told Xiang Gong: 'Trouble has been born.' Zhen then pursued the Qin generals. The Qin generals had already crossed the river and were in the boats. They kowtowed in thanks but ultimately refused to return.

Three years later, Qin indeed sent Meng Ming to attack Jin in revenge for the defeat at Xiao, capturing Wang of Jin and returning home. In the fourth year, Duke Mu of Qin launched a major invasion of our territory, crossed the Yellow River, captured Wangguan, buried the corpses from Xiao, and departed. Jin was terrified and dared not venture out, so they fortified their cities and defended them. In the fifth year, Jin attacked Qin, captured Xincheng, in revenge for the Wangguan campaign.

In the eighth month of the seventh year, Duke Xiang died. The crown prince Yi Gao was still young. Because of the succession difficulties, the Jin people desired to establish an older ruler. Zhao Dun said: 'Establish Xiang Gong's younger brother Yong. He is good and virtuous, and elder. The former lord loved him; Moreover, he has close ties to Qin, with whom we have longstanding friendly relations. Establishing the good is solid. Serving the elder is orderly. Honoring love is filial. Tying old friendships is peaceful.' Jia Ji said: 'His younger brother Le would be better. Chen Ying was favored by two lords. Establishing his son, the people must settle with him.' Zhao Dun said: 'Chen Ying is base, ranked below the nine men. What awe does his son have! Moreover, being the favorite of two rulers is improper. For the former lord's son, he could not seek greatness and went out to a small country. That is eccentric. Mother licentious, son eccentric, no authority; Chen is small and distant, with no support. What can be done!' They sent Shi Hui to Qin to welcome Prince Yong. Jia Ji also sent envoys to summon Prince Le from Chen. Zhao Dun dismissed Jia Ji because he had assassinated Yang Chufu. In the tenth month, Duke Xiang was buried. In the eleventh month, Jia Ji fled to the Di. That same year, Duke Mu of Qin also died.

éˆå…¬å…ƒå¹´å››æœˆï¼Œç§¦åº·å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ˜”æ–‡å…¬ä¹‹å…¥ä¹Ÿç„¡è¡›ï¼Œæ•…æœ‰å‘‚ã€éƒ¤ä¹‹æ‚£ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒå¤šèˆ‡å…¬å­é›è¡›ã€‚ å¤ªå­æ¯ç¹†å¬´æ—¥å¤œæŠ±å¤ªå­ä»¥è™Ÿæ³£æ–¼æœï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå…ˆå›ä½•ç½ªï¼Ÿ å…¶å—£äº¦ä½•ç½ªï¼Ÿ èˆé©è€Œå¤–æ±‚å›ï¼Œå°‡å®‰ç½®æ­¤ï¼Ÿã€ å‡ºæœï¼Œå‰‡æŠ±ä»¥é©è¶™ç›¾æ‰€ï¼Œé “é¦–æ›°ï¼šã€Œå…ˆå›å¥‰æ­¤å­è€Œå±¬ä¹‹å­ï¼Œæ›°ã€æ­¤å­æï¼Œå¾å—å…¶è³œï¼› ä¸æï¼Œå¾æ€¨å­ã€ã€‚ ä»Šå›å’ï¼Œè¨€çŒ¶åœ¨è€³ï¼Œè€Œæ£„ä¹‹ï¼Œè‹¥ä½•ï¼Ÿã€ è¶™ç›¾èˆ‡è«¸å¤§å¤«çš†æ‚£ç¹†å¬´ï¼Œä¸”ç•èª…ï¼Œä¹ƒèƒŒæ‰€è¿è€Œç«‹å¤ªå­å¤·çš‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºéˆå…¬ã€‚ ç™¼å…µä»¥è·ç§¦é€å…¬å­é›è€…ã€‚ è¶™ç›¾ç‚ºå°‡ï¼Œå¾€æ“Šç§¦ï¼Œæ•—ä¹‹ä»¤ç‹ã€‚ å…ˆè”‘ã€éš¨æœƒäº¡å¥”ç§¦ã€‚ ç§‹ï¼Œé½Šã€å®‹ã€è¡›ã€é„­ã€æ›¹ã€è¨±å›çš†æœƒè¶™ç›¾ï¼Œç›Ÿæ–¼æ‰ˆï¼Œä»¥éˆå…¬åˆç«‹æ•…ä¹Ÿã€‚
In Ling Gong's first year, fourth month, Qin Kang Gong said: 'Formerly when Wen Gong entered, there was no guard, therefore there were Lu and Xi troubles.' They then provided Prince Yong with a substantial bodyguard. The crown prince's mother Mu Ying, day and night, embraced the crown prince and wailed weeping at court, saying: 'What crime did the former lord commit? What crime did his successor also commit? Abandon the proper heir and seek a lord from outside. Where will you place this child?' Leaving court, she then embraced him and went to Zhao Dun's place, knocked her head and said: 'The former lord presented this son and entrusted him to you, saying "this son is talented, I receive his favor; Worthless, I resent you".' Now the lord has died, the words are still in our ears, yet you abandon him. How is this?' Zhao Dun and the other ministers were all troubled by Muying and feared execution, so they abandoned the candidate they had welcomed and instead established the crown prince Yi Gao as Duke Ling. They dispatched troops to oppose those escorting Prince Yong from Qin. Zhao Dun served as commander and went to attack Qin, defeating them at Linghu. Xian Mie and Sui Hui fled to Qin. In autumn, the rulers of Qi, Song, Wei, Zheng, Cao, and Xu all met with Zhao Dun and formed an alliance at Hu, because Duke Ling had just ascended the throne.

å››å¹´ï¼Œä¼ç§¦ï¼Œå–å°‘æ¢ã€‚ ç§¦äº¦å–æ™‰ä¹‹éƒ©ã€‚ å…­å¹´ï¼Œç§¦åº·å…¬ä¼æ™‰ï¼Œå–ç¾ˆé¦¬ã€‚ æ™‰ä¾¯æ€’ï¼Œä½¿è¶™ç›¾ã€è¶™ç©¿ã€éƒ¤ç¼ºæ“Šç§¦ï¼Œå¤§æˆ°æ²³æ›²ï¼Œè¶™ç©¿æœ€æœ‰åŠŸã€‚ ä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰å…­å¿æ‚£éš¨æœƒä¹‹åœ¨ç§¦ï¼Œå¸¸ç‚ºæ™‰äº‚ï¼Œä¹ƒè©³ä»¤é­å£½é¤˜åæ™‰é™ç§¦ã€‚ ç§¦ä½¿éš¨æœƒä¹‹é­ï¼Œå› åŸ·æœƒä»¥æ­¸æ™‰ã€‚
In the fourth year, they attacked Qin and captured Shaoliang. Qin also captured Jin's Xiao. In the sixth year, Duke Kang of Qin attacked Jin and captured Jima. The Duke of Jin was furious and sent Zhao Dun, Zhao Chuan, and Xi Que to attack Qin. They fought a major battle at Hequ, with Zhao Chuan distinguishing himself most. In the seventh year, the Jin Six Ministers were troubled that Sui Hui was in Qin and often caused disorder for Jin, so they falsely ordered Wei Shou Yu to rebel against Jin and surrender to Qin. Qin sent Sui Hui to Wei, then seized him and returned him to Jin.

å…«å¹´ï¼Œå‘¨é ƒç‹å´©ï¼Œå…¬å¿çˆ­æ¬Šï¼Œæ•…ä¸èµ´ã€‚ æ™‰ä½¿è¶™ç›¾ä»¥è»Šå…«ç™¾ä¹˜å¹³å‘¨äº‚è€Œç«‹åŒ¡ç‹ã€‚ æ˜¯å¹´ï¼Œæ¥šèŠç‹åˆå³ä½ã€‚ åäºŒå¹´ï¼Œé½Šäººå¼’å…¶å›æ‡¿å…¬ã€‚
In the eighth year, King Qing of Zhou died. The nobles and ministers were contending for power, so they did not attend the funeral. Jin sent Zhao Dun with eight hundred chariots to pacify the Zhou disorders and establish King Kuang. That year, King Zhuang of Chu first ascended the throne. In the twelfth year, the people of Qi assassinated their ruler Duke Yi.

åå››å¹´ï¼Œéˆå…¬å£¯ï¼Œä¾ˆï¼Œåšæ–‚ä»¥å½«å¢»ã€‚ å¾è‡ºä¸Šå½ˆäººï¼Œè§€å…¶é¿ä¸¸ä¹Ÿã€‚ å®°å¤«èƒ¹ç†Šè¹¯ä¸ç†Ÿï¼Œéˆå…¬æ€’ï¼Œæ®ºå®°å¤«ï¼Œä½¿å©¦äººæŒå…¶å°¸å‡ºæ£„ä¹‹ï¼Œéæœã€‚ è¶™ç›¾ã€éš¨æœƒå‰æ•¸è««ï¼Œä¸è½ï¼› å·²åˆè¦‹æ­»äººæ‰‹ï¼ŒäºŒäººå‰è««ã€‚ éš¨æœƒå…ˆè««ï¼Œä¸è½ã€‚ éˆå…¬æ‚£ä¹‹ï¼Œä½¿é‰éº‘åˆºè¶™ç›¾ã€‚ ç›¾é–¨é–€é–‹ï¼Œå±…è™•ç¯€ï¼Œé‰éº‘é€€ï¼Œå˜†æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ®ºå¿ è‡£ï¼Œæ£„å›å‘½ï¼Œç½ªä¸€ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ é‚è§¸æ¨¹è€Œæ­»ã€‚
In the fourteenth year, Duke Ling had grown up and became extravagant, imposing heavy taxes to decorate his walls. From the tower he shot pellets at people, watching them dodge. The cook stewed bear paws but they were undercooked. Duke Ling was furious, killed the cook, and had women carry his corpse out and discard it, parading it through the court. Zhao Dun and Sui Hui had previously repeatedly admonished him, but he did not listen; He had already once more seen a dead man's hand, and the two men admonished him to his face. Sui Hui had previously admonished him, but he would not listen. Duke Ling was troubled by this and sent Chuni to assassinate Zhao Dun. Dun's chamber door was open, his dwelling was moderate. Chu Ni retreated and sighed, saying: 'Killing a loyal minister, abandoning the lord's command - it is the same crime.' He then crashed into a tree and died.

åˆï¼Œç›¾å¸¸ç”°é¦–å±±ï¼Œè¦‹æ¡‘ä¸‹æœ‰é¤“äººã€‚ é¤“äººï¼Œç¤ºç‡æ˜ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç›¾èˆ‡ä¹‹é£Ÿï¼Œé£Ÿå…¶åŠã€‚ å•å…¶æ•…ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå®¦ä¸‰å¹´ï¼ŒæœªçŸ¥æ¯ä¹‹å­˜ä¸ï¼Œé¡˜éºæ¯ã€‚ã€ ç›¾ç¾©ä¹‹ï¼Œç›Šèˆ‡ä¹‹é£¯è‚‰ã€‚ å·²è€Œç‚ºæ™‰å®°å¤«ï¼Œè¶™ç›¾å¼—å¾©çŸ¥ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¹æœˆï¼Œæ™‰éˆå…¬é£²è¶™ç›¾é…’ï¼Œä¼ç”²å°‡æ”»ç›¾ã€‚ å…¬å®°ç¤ºç‡æ˜çŸ¥ä¹‹ï¼Œæç›¾é†‰ä¸èƒ½èµ·ï¼Œè€Œé€²æ›°ï¼šã€Œå›è³œè‡£ï¼Œè§´ä¸‰è¡Œå¯ä»¥ç½·ã€‚ã€ æ¬²ä»¥å»è¶™ç›¾ï¼Œä»¤å…ˆï¼Œæ¯‹åŠé›£ã€‚ ç›¾æ—¢å»ï¼Œéˆå…¬ä¼å£«æœªæœƒï¼Œå…ˆç¸±é½§ç‹—åæ•–ã€‚ æ˜ç‚ºç›¾ææ®ºç‹—ã€‚ ç›¾æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ£„äººç”¨ç‹—ï¼Œé›–çŒ›ä½•ç‚ºã€‚ã€ ç„¶ä¸çŸ¥æ˜ä¹‹ç‚ºé™°å¾·ä¹Ÿã€‚ å·²è€Œéˆå…¬ç¸±ä¼å£«å‡ºé€è¶™ç›¾ï¼Œç¤ºç‡æ˜åæ“Šéˆå…¬ä¹‹ä¼å£«ï¼Œä¼å£«ä¸èƒ½é€²ï¼Œè€Œç«Ÿè„«ç›¾ã€‚ ç›¾å•å…¶æ•…ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œæˆ‘æ¡‘ä¸‹é¤“äººã€‚ã€ å•å…¶åï¼Œå¼—å‘Šã€‚ æ˜äº¦å› äº¡å»ã€‚
Initially, Zhao Dun often hunted at Shou Mountain and saw a starving man beneath a mulberry tree. The starving man was Shiming. Zhao Dun gave him food, and he ate only half of it. Asked the reason, he said: 'I have served for three years, do not know if my mother is alive or not. I wish to send this to my mother.' Zhao Dun admired his restraint and gave him even more rice and meat. Later he became the chief cook in Jin, and Zhao Dun did not recognize him. In the ninth month, Duke Ling of Jin drank wine with Zhao Dun, but had hidden armored troops ready to attack him. The duke's chef Shi Mi Ming knew of it. He feared that if Dun got drunk he could not rise, so he advanced and said: 'The lord grants the minister. Three rounds of cups can cease.' He wanted to get rid of Zhao Dun and ordered him to leave first, so he would not be caught in the attack. Zhao Dun had already left. Duke Ling's hidden soldiers were not yet in position, so he first unleashed a ferocious dog named Ao. Ming wrestled the dog and killed it to protect Zhao Dun. Dun said: 'Abandoning people and using dogs - though fierce, what is it for?' But he did not know that Ming's was hidden virtue. Later Ling Gong released the hidden soldiers to go pursue Zhao Dun. Shi Mi Ming counterattacked Ling Gong's hidden soldiers. The hidden soldiers could not advance, and he ultimately rescued Dun. Dun asked the reason, and he said: 'I am the starving person under the mulberry tree.' When asked his name, he refused to tell it. Ming also fled as a result.

Zhao Dun then fled, but had not yet left Jin's territory. On the day Yichou, Zhao Dun's younger brother General Zhao Chuan launched a surprise attack and assassinated Duke Ling in the peach garden, then welcomed Zhao Dun back. Zhao Dun was always noble and obtained the people's harmony; Duke Ling was young and extravagant. The people did not support him, so assassinating him was easy. Zhao Dun resumed his office. Jin grand historian Dong Hu wrote: 'Zhao Dun assassinated his lord,' and showed it at court. Dun said: 'The assassin was Zhao Chuan. I have no crime.' The grand historian said: 'You are the chief minister, but you fled without leaving the borders, returned without executing the state disorder. If not you, then who?' Kong Qiu heard of it and said: 'Dong Hu was an ancient good historian. His writing method did not conceal. Xuanzhi was a worthy minister. He suffered blame for upholding the law. It is a pity. Going out the borders would have exempted him.'

Zhao Dun sent Zhao Chuan to welcome Duke Xiang's younger brother Heitun from Zhou and install him as ruler. He became Duke Cheng.

Duke Cheng was Duke Wen's youngest son, whose mother was a woman from Zhou. On the day Renshen, he held court at the Wu Palace.

In the seventh year, Duke Cheng contended for supremacy with King Zhuang of Chu and assembled the feudal lords at Hu. Chen feared Chu and did not attend. In the third year, King Zhuang of Chu besieged Zheng, and Zheng urgently appealed to Jin for help. Jin sent Xun Linfu to command the central army, Sui Hui the upper army, Zhao Shuo the lower army, with Xi Ke, Luan Shu, Xian Hu, Han Jue, and Gong Shuo as their assistants. In the sixth month, they reached the Yellow River. They heard that Chu had already subdued Zheng. The Marquis of Zheng went bare-chested to make peace with them and departed. Xun Linfu wanted to return. Xian Hu said: 'All came to save Zheng. Not arriving is not permissible. The generals and officers will have separate hearts.' They finally crossed the river. Chu had already conquered Zheng and wanted to water their horses at the river for show before departing. Chu fought a major battle with the Jin army. Zheng had recently submitted to Chu. Fearing Chu's power, they turned and helped Chu attack Jin instead. The Jin army was defeated and fled to the river. They fought to cross, and the boats were overloaded with people. Chu captured our general Zhi Ying. Upon returning, Lin Fu said: 'I was the commander general. The army was defeated and I should be executed. I request death.' Duke Jing wanted to agree to it. Sui Hui said: 'Formerly Wen Gong battled with Chu at Cheng Pu. Cheng Wang returned and killed Zi Yu, and Wen Gong was then happy. Now Chu has already defeated our army. Again executing their general - this assists Chu in killing our enemy.' They then desisted.

In the fourth year, Xian Hu's reckless plan caused the defeat of the Jin army north of the river. Fearing execution, he fled to the Di and plotted with them to attack Jin. Jin became aware of this and executed Xian Hu's entire clan. Xian Hu was the son of Xian Zhen.

In the sixth year, Chu attacked Song. Song came to urgently report to Jin. Jin desired to save it. Bo Zong advised: 'Chu - heaven has just opened it. It cannot be resisted.' They then sent Xie Yang to rescue Song. The Zheng people seized him and handed him over to Chu. Chu generously rewarded him and made him reverse his words, ordering Song to immediately surrender. Xie Yang feigned agreement, but ultimately delivered the Jin lord's message. Chu wanted to kill him, but some advised against it, so they sent Xie Yang back. In the seventh year, Jin sent Sui Hui to exterminate the Red Di.

In the eighth year, Xi Ke was sent to Qi. Duke Qing of Qi's mother watched from a tower and laughed at him. The reason was that Xi Ke was hunchbacked, while the envoy from Lu was lame, and the envoy from Wei was one-eyed. Therefore, Qi also had similarly afflicted people guide the guests. Xi Ke was angered and returned to the river upper. He said: 'Those who do not repay Qi - the river lord will see it!' Upon returning to his state, he requested permission from the lord to attack Qi. Jing Gong asked and knew the reason. He said: 'Your resentment - how does it suffice to trouble the country!' The lord did not heed him. Wei Wen Zi requested to retire due to old age, avoiding Xi Ke, who then took charge of the government.

In the eleventh year, during spring, Qi attacked Lu and captured Long. Lu appealed urgently to Wei for help. Both Wei and Lu appealed urgently to Jin through Xi Ke. Jin then sent Xi Ke, Luan Shu, and Han Jue with eight hundred war chariots to join with Lu and Wei in attacking Qi. In summer, they fought Duke Qing at Ai, wounding and trapping him. Duke Qing then switched places with his charioteer, climbed down to drink some water, and thus managed to escape. The Qi army was defeated and fled. Jin pursued them northward all the way to Qi. Duke Qing offered precious vessels to sue for peace, but they refused to listen. Xi Ke said: 'We must obtain Xiao Tong's nephew's son as hostage.' The Qi envoy said: 'Xiao Tong's nephew's son is Qing Gong's mother; Qing Gong's mother is like the Jin lord's mother. How must we obtain her? Not righteous. We request to battle again.' Jin then agreed to peace and withdrew.

In the sixteenth year, Zi Fan, a general of Chu, resented Wu Chen and exterminated his clan. Wu Chen was angered and sent Zi Fan a letter saying: 'I must make you weary from running orders!' Wu Chen then requested to be sent as envoy to Wu, had his son serve as Wu's diplomatic envoy, and taught the Wu people chariot warfare and military tactics. In the seventeenth year, they executed Zhao Tong and Zhao Kuo, exterminating their entire clan. Han Jue said: 'How can Zhao Shuai and Zhao Dun's merit be forgotten? How can we cut off the sacrifices!' They then reinstated Zhao Wu, Zhao's son by a concubine, as head of the Zhao clan and restored his fief to him.

In the first year of Duke Li's reign, newly ascended to the throne, he sought to reconcile with the other lords and formed an alliance with Duke Huan of Qin on opposite banks of the river. In the fifth year, the three Xi clans slandered Bo Zong and had him executed. Bo Zong had brought this calamity upon himself because he was fond of giving forthright advice. Because of this, the people of the state no longer supported Duke Li.

å…­å¹´æ˜¥ï¼Œé„­å€æ™‰èˆ‡æ¥šç›Ÿï¼Œæ™‰æ€’ã€‚ æ¬’æ›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å¯ä»¥ç•¶å¾ä¸–è€Œå¤±è«¸ä¾¯ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒç™¼å…µã€‚ å²å…¬è‡ªå°‡ï¼Œäº”æœˆåº¦æ²³ã€‚ èæ¥šå…µä¾†æ•‘ï¼ŒèŒƒæ–‡å­è«‹å…¬æ¬²é‚„ã€‚ éƒ¤è‡³æ›°ï¼šã€Œç™¼å…µèª…é€†ï¼Œè¦‹å½Šè¾Ÿä¹‹ï¼Œç„¡ä»¥ä»¤è«¸ä¾¯ã€‚ã€ é‚èˆ‡æˆ°ã€‚ ç™¸å·³ï¼Œå°„ä¸­æ¥šå…±ç‹ç›®ï¼Œæ¥šå…µæ•—æ–¼é„¢é™µã€‚ å­åæ”¶é¤˜å…µï¼Œæ‹Šå¾ªæ¬²å¾©æˆ°ï¼Œæ™‰æ‚£ä¹‹ã€‚ å…±ç‹å¬å­åï¼Œå…¶ä¾è€…è±é™½ç©€é€²é…’ï¼Œå­åé†‰ï¼Œä¸èƒ½è¦‹ã€‚ ç‹æ€’ï¼Œè®“å­åï¼Œå­åæ­»ã€‚ ç‹é‚å¼•å…µæ­¸ã€‚ æ™‰ç”±æ­¤å¨è«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œæ¬²ä»¥ä»¤å¤©ä¸‹æ±‚éœ¸ã€‚
In the sixth year, during spring, Zheng betrayed Jin and formed an alliance with Chu. Jin was furious. Luan Shu said: 'We cannot lose the feudal lords during our generation.' They then mobilized their army. Duke Li personally commanded the expedition. In the fifth month, they crossed the Yellow River. They heard that Chu troops were coming to Zheng's rescue. Fan Wen Zi urged the duke to turn back. Xi Zhi said: 'We dispatched troops to execute the rebellious. To see the strong and avoid them - how can we command the feudal lords?' They then engaged them in battle. On the day Guisi, an arrow struck King Gong of Chu in the eye. The Chu army was defeated at Yanling. Zi Fan rallied the surviving troops and reassured them, intending to renew the battle. Jin was alarmed by this. King Gong summoned Zi Fan. His attendant Shu Yang Gu offered him wine. Zi Fan got drunk and could not appear before him. The king was furious and berated Zi Fan. Zi Fan committed suicide. The king then led his troops back home. From this point on, Jin intimidated the other lords and aspired to command the world and achieve hegemony.

å²å…¬å¤šå¤–å¬–å§¬ï¼Œæ­¸ï¼Œæ¬²ç›¡å»ç¾¤å¤§å¤«è€Œç«‹è«¸å§¬å…„å¼Ÿã€‚ å¯µå§¬å…„æ›°èƒ¥ç«¥ï¼Œå˜—èˆ‡éƒ¤è‡³æœ‰æ€¨ï¼ŒåŠæ¬’æ›¸åˆæ€¨éƒ¤è‡³ä¸ç”¨å…¶è¨ˆè€Œé‚æ•—æ¥šï¼Œä¹ƒä½¿äººé–’è¬æ¥šã€‚ æ¥šä¾†è©å²å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œé„¢é™µä¹‹æˆ°ï¼Œå¯¦è‡³å¬æ¥šï¼Œæ¬²ä½œäº‚ï¼Œå…§å­å‘¨ç«‹ä¹‹ã€‚ æœƒèˆ‡åœ‹ä¸å…·ï¼Œæ˜¯ä»¥äº‹ä¸æˆã€‚ã€ å²å…¬å‘Šæ¬’æ›¸ã€‚ æ¬’æ›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œå…¶æ®†æœ‰çŸ£ï¼ é¡˜å…¬è©¦ä½¿äººä¹‹å‘¨å¾®è€ƒä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æœä½¿éƒ¤è‡³æ–¼å‘¨ã€‚ æ¬’æ›¸åˆä½¿å…¬å­å‘¨è¦‹éƒ¤è‡³ï¼Œéƒ¤è‡³ä¸çŸ¥è¦‹è³£ä¹Ÿã€‚ å²å…¬é©—ä¹‹ï¼Œä¿¡ç„¶ï¼Œé‚æ€¨éƒ¤è‡³ï¼Œæ¬²æ®ºä¹‹ã€‚ å…«å¹´ï¼Œå²å…¬çµï¼Œèˆ‡å§¬é£²ï¼Œéƒ¤è‡³æ®ºè±•å¥‰é€²ï¼Œå®¦è€…å¥ªä¹‹ã€‚ éƒ¤è‡³å°„æ®ºå®¦è€…ã€‚ å…¬æ€’ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå­£å­æ¬ºäºˆï¼ã€ å°‡èª…ä¸‰éƒ¤ï¼Œæœªç™¼ä¹Ÿã€‚ éƒ¤é‰¤æ¬²æ”»å…¬ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œæˆ‘é›–æ­»ï¼Œå…¬äº¦ç—…çŸ£ã€‚ã€ éƒ¤è‡³æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¿¡ä¸åå›ï¼Œæ™ºä¸å®³æ°‘ï¼Œå‹‡ä¸ä½œäº‚ã€‚ å¤±æ­¤ä¸‰è€…ï¼Œèª°èˆ‡æˆ‘ï¼Ÿ æˆ‘æ­»è€³ï¼ã€ åäºŒæœˆå£¬åˆï¼Œå…¬ä»¤èƒ¥ç«¥ä»¥å…µå…«ç™¾äººè¥²æ”»æ®ºä¸‰éƒ¤ã€‚ èƒ¥ç«¥å› ä»¥åŠ«æ¬’æ›¸ã€ä¸­è¡Œåƒäºæœï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸æ®ºäºŒå­ï¼Œæ‚£å¿…åŠå…¬ã€‚ã€ å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸€æ—¦æ®ºä¸‰å¿ï¼Œå¯¡äººä¸å¿ç›Šä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œäººå°‡å¿å›ã€‚ã€ å…¬å¼—è½ï¼Œè¬æ¬’æ›¸ç­‰ä»¥èª…éƒ¤æ°ç½ªï¼šã€Œå¤§å¤«å¾©ä½ã€‚ã€ äºŒå­é “é¦–æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¹¸ç”šå¹¸ç”šï¼ã€ å…¬ä½¿èƒ¥ç«¥ç‚ºå¿ã€‚ é–æœˆä¹™å¯ï¼Œå²å…¬æ¸¸åŒ é©ªæ°ï¼Œæ¬’æ›¸ã€ä¸­è¡Œåƒä»¥å…¶é»¨è¥²æ•å²å…¬ï¼Œå›šä¹‹ï¼Œæ®ºèƒ¥ç«¥ï¼Œè€Œä½¿äººè¿å…¬å­å‘¨äºå‘¨è€Œç«‹ä¹‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ‚¼å…¬ã€‚
Duke Li had many favored concubines from outside the nobility. Upon returning home, he wanted to dismiss all the ministers and install his concubines' brothers in their place. The favored concubine's brother was named Xu Tong. He had long harbored resentment against Xi Zhi, and now Luan Shu also resented Xi Zhi for not adopting his strategy and thereby allowing Chu to be defeated. So Xu Tong sent agents to secretly apologize to Chu. Chu came and deceived Li Gong, saying: 'In the Yan Ling battle, Xi Zhi summoned Chu and desired to make rebellion. Inner son Zhou would establish him. The meeting with the state was not prepared, therefore the matter was not accomplished.' Duke Li informed Luan Shu. Luan Shu said: 'I suspect something like this is happening!' I wish the duke would try sending people to Zhou to secretly examine it.' Sure enough, they sent Xi Zhi on a mission to Zhou. Luan Shu then sent Prince Zhou to meet with Xi Zhi. Xi Zhi had no idea he was being set up for betrayal. Duke Li investigated and confirmed it was true. He then grew resentful of Xi Zhi and wanted to have him executed. In the eighth year, Duke Li went hunting and was drinking with his concubine. Xi Zhi slaughtered a pig and offered it to them. A eunuch snatched it away. Xi Zhi shot and killed the eunuch. The duke was angered and said: 'Ji Zi deceives me!' He was about to execute the three Xi clans, but had not yet given the order. Xi Gou desired to attack the duke and said: 'Though I die, the duke will also be ill.' Xi Zhi said: 'Faithfulness does not betray the lord. Wisdom does not harm the people. Courage does not make rebellion. If I lose these three, who is with me? I will only die!' In the twelfth month, on the day Renwu, the duke ordered Xu Tong to launch a surprise attack with eight hundred troops and execute the three Xi clans. Xu Tong then kidnapped Luan Shu and Zhong Xing Yan at court and said: 'If we do not kill these two sons, the trouble will certainly reach the duke.' The duke said: 'To suddenly kill three ministers - I cannot bear it moreover.' He answered: 'People will bear the lord.' The duke did not listen and apologized to Luan Shu etc. for the crime of executing the Xi clan: 'Grandees resume your positions.' The two sons knocked their heads and said: 'Extremely fortunate! Extremely fortunate!' The duke appointed Xu Tong as a minister. In the intercalary month, on the day Yimao, Duke Li visited the Jiangli clan. Luan Shu and Zhong Xing Yan launched a surprise attack with their followers, captured Duke Li, imprisoned him, executed Xu Tong, and sent men to welcome Prince Zhou from Zhou and install him as ruler. This was Duke Dao.
111
æ‚¼å…¬å…ƒå¹´æ­£æœˆåºšç”³ï¼Œæ¬’æ›¸ã€ä¸­è¡Œåƒå¼’å²å…¬ï¼Œè‘¬ä¹‹ä»¥ä¸€ä¹˜è»Šã€‚ å²å…¬å›šå…­æ—¥æ­»ï¼Œæ­»åæ—¥åºšåˆï¼Œæ™ºç½ƒè¿å…¬å­å‘¨ä¾†ï¼Œè‡³çµ³ï¼Œåˆ‘é›èˆ‡å¤§å¤«ç›Ÿè€Œç«‹ä¹‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ‚¼å…¬ã€‚ è¾›å·³ï¼Œæœæ­¦å®®ã€‚ äºŒæœˆä¹™é…‰ï¼Œå³ä½ã€‚
In the first year of Duke Dao, first month on the day Gengshen, Luan Shu and Zhong Xing Yan assassinated Duke Li and buried him with only a single chariot. Duke Li was imprisoned for six days and died. Ten days after his death, on the day Gengwu, Zhi Ying went to welcome Prince Zhou. They arrived at Jiang, performed a blood oath with the ministers by cutting a chicken, and installed him as ruler. This was Duke Dao. On the day Xinsi, he held court at the Wu Palace. In the second month, on the day Yiyou, he formally ascended the throne.

æ‚¼å…¬å‘¨è€…ï¼Œå…¶å¤§çˆ¶æ·ï¼Œæ™‰è¥„å…¬å°‘å­ä¹Ÿï¼Œä¸å¾—ç«‹ï¼Œè™Ÿç‚ºæ¡“å”ï¼Œæ¡“å”æœ€æ„›ã€‚ æ¡“å”ç”Ÿæƒ ä¼¯è«‡ï¼Œè«‡ç”Ÿæ‚¼å…¬å‘¨ã€‚ å‘¨ä¹‹ç«‹ï¼Œå¹´åå››çŸ£ã€‚ æ‚¼å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤§çˆ¶ã€çˆ¶çš†ä¸å¾—ç«‹è€Œè¾Ÿé›£æ–¼å‘¨ï¼Œå®¢æ­»ç„‰ã€‚ å¯¡äººè‡ªä»¥ç–é ï¼Œæ¯‹å¹¾ç‚ºå›ã€‚ ä»Šå¤§å¤«ä¸å¿˜æ–‡ã€è¥„ä¹‹æ„è€Œæƒ ç«‹æ¡“å”ä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œè³´å®—å»Ÿå¤§å¤«ä¹‹éˆï¼Œå¾—å¥‰æ™‰ç¥€ï¼Œè±ˆæ•¢ä¸æˆ°æˆ°ä¹ï¼Ÿ å¤§å¤«å…¶äº¦ä½å¯¡äººï¼ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯é€ä¸è‡£è€…ä¸ƒäººï¼Œä¿®èˆŠåŠŸï¼Œæ–½å¾·æƒ ï¼Œæ”¶æ–‡å…¬å…¥æ™‚åŠŸè‡£å¾Œã€‚ ç§‹ï¼Œä¼é„­ã€‚ é„­å¸«æ•—ï¼Œé‚è‡³é™³ã€‚
Duke Dao, whose name was Zhou, had as his grandfather Jie, the youngest son of Duke Xiang of Jin. Jie was not able to become ruler and was known as Uncle Huan. Uncle Huan was the most beloved. Uncle Huan fathered Hui Bo Tan, and Tan fathered Duke Dao Zhou. When Zhou was established, he was fourteen years old. Dao Gong said: 'My grandfather and father were all not able to be established and avoided difficulty at Zhou, dying there as guests. I myself am too distantly related and hardly worthy of becoming ruler. Now the grandees have not forgotten Wen and Xiang's intention and kindly established Huan Shu's successor. Relying on the ancestral temple and grandees' spirit, I have obtained to serve Jin's sacrifices. How dare I not tremble?' Grandees, you must also assist me!' Thereupon he expelled seven disloyal subjects, honored past achievements, bestowed favors and kindness, and gathered the descendants of the meritorious officials from Duke Wen's return. In autumn, they attacked Zheng. The Zheng army was defeated, and they then advanced to Chen.

ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰æœƒè«¸ä¾¯ã€‚ æ‚¼å…¬å•ç¾¤è‡£å¯ç”¨è€…ï¼Œç¥å‚’èˆ‰è§£ç‹ã€‚ è§£ç‹ï¼Œå‚’ä¹‹ä»‡ã€‚ å¾©å•ï¼Œèˆ‰å…¶å­ç¥åˆã€‚ å›å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œç¥å‚’å¯è¬‚ä¸é»¨çŸ£ï¼ å¤–èˆ‰ä¸éš±ä»‡ï¼Œå…§èˆ‰ä¸éš±å­ã€‚ã€ æ–¹æœƒè«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œæ‚¼å…¬å¼Ÿæ¥Šå¹²äº‚è¡Œï¼Œé­çµ³æˆ®å…¶ä»†ã€‚ æ‚¼å…¬æ€’ï¼Œæˆ–è««å…¬ï¼Œå…¬å’è³¢çµ³ï¼Œä»»ä¹‹æ”¿ï¼Œä½¿å’Œæˆï¼Œæˆå¤§è¦ªé™„ã€‚ åä¸€å¹´ï¼Œæ‚¼å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡ªå¾ç”¨é­çµ³ï¼Œä¹åˆè«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œå’Œæˆã€ç¿Ÿï¼Œé­å­ä¹‹åŠ›ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ è³œä¹‹æ¨‚ï¼Œä¸‰è®“ä¹ƒå—ä¹‹ã€‚ å†¬ï¼Œç§¦å–æˆ‘æ«Ÿã€‚
In the third year, Jin convened a meeting of the feudal lords. Duke Dao asked his ministers who could be employed, and Qi Xi recommended Xie Hu. Xie Hu was Xi's enemy. When he asked again, Qi Xi recommended his own son, Qi Wu. The superior man said: 'Qi Xi can be called not partisan! Externally he raises without concealing enemies, internally he raises without concealing sons.' Just as they were convening the feudal lords, Duke Dao's younger brother Yang Gan disrupted the procession. Wei Jiang executed his charioteer. Duke Dao was furious. Some ministers advised him, and he eventually recognized Wei Jiang's worth, entrusted him with governance, and had him pacify the Rong barbarians. The Rong became greatly attached to Jin. In the eleventh year, Dao Gong said: 'Since I used Wei Jiang, nine times I united the feudal lords and pacified the Rong and Di. This is Wei Zi's strength.' He granted him the gift of musical instruments. He declined three times before accepting them. In winter, Qin captured our town of Li.

åå››å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰ä½¿å…­å¿ç‡è«¸ä¾¯ä¼ç§¦ï¼Œåº¦æ¶‡ï¼Œå¤§æ•—ç§¦è»ï¼Œè‡³æ£«æ—è€Œå»ã€‚
In the fourteenth year, Jin sent its six ministers to lead the feudal lords in attacking Qin. They crossed the Jing River, inflicted a major defeat on the Qin army, advanced to Yu Forest, and then withdrew.

åäº”å¹´ï¼Œæ‚¼å…¬å•æ²»åœ‹æ–¼å¸«æ› ã€‚ å¸«æ› æ›°ï¼šã€ŒæƒŸä»ç¾©ç‚ºæœ¬ã€‚ã€ å†¬ï¼Œæ‚¼å…¬å’ï¼Œå­å¹³å…¬å½ªç«‹ã€‚
In the fifteenth year, Duke Dao consulted Shi Kuang about governing the state. Shi Kuang said: 'Only benevolence and righteousness are the foundation.' In winter, Duke Dao passed away, and his son Biao ascended as Duke Ping.

å¹³å…¬å…ƒå¹´ï¼Œä¼é½Šï¼Œé½Šéˆå…¬èˆ‡æˆ°é¡ä¸‹ï¼Œé½Šå¸«æ•—èµ°ã€‚ æ™å¬°æ›°ï¼šã€Œå›äº¦æ¯‹å‹‡ï¼Œä½•ä¸æ­¢æˆ°ï¼Ÿã€ é‚å»ã€‚ æ™‰è¿½ï¼Œé‚åœè‡¨è‘ï¼Œç›¡ç‡’å± å…¶éƒ­ä¸­ã€‚ æ±è‡³è† ï¼Œå—è‡³æ²‚ï¼Œé½Šçš†åŸå®ˆï¼Œæ™‰ä¹ƒå¼•å…µæ­¸ã€‚
In the first year of Duke Ping, they attacked Qi. Duke Ling of Qi fought them at Mi Hill, but the Qi army was defeated and fled. Yan Ying said: 'The lord is also not courageous. Why not stop the battle?' He then withdrew. Jin pursued them, laid siege to Linzi, and burned and slaughtered everyone in the outer city. From east to Jiao and south to Yi, all of Qi fortified their cities and defended them. Jin then withdrew its army.

å…­å¹´ï¼Œé­¯è¥„å…¬æœæ™‰ã€‚ æ™‰æ¬’é€æœ‰ç½ªï¼Œå¥”é½Šã€‚ å…«å¹´ï¼Œé½ŠèŠå…¬å¾®é£æ¬’é€æ–¼æ›²æ²ƒï¼Œä»¥å…µéš¨ä¹‹ã€‚ é½Šå…µä¸Šå¤ªè¡Œï¼Œæ¬’é€å¾æ›²æ²ƒä¸­åï¼Œè¥²å…¥çµ³ã€‚ çµ³ä¸æˆ’ï¼Œå¹³å…¬æ¬²è‡ªæ®ºï¼ŒèŒƒç»å­æ­¢å…¬ï¼Œä»¥å…¶å¾’æ“Šé€ï¼Œé€æ•—èµ°æ›²æ²ƒã€‚ æ›²æ²ƒæ”»é€ï¼Œé€æ­»ï¼Œé‚æ»…æ¬’æ°å®—ã€‚ é€è€…ï¼Œæ¬’æ›¸å­«ä¹Ÿã€‚ å…¶å…¥çµ³ï¼Œèˆ‡é­æ°è¬€ã€‚ é½ŠèŠå…¬èé€æ•—ï¼Œä¹ƒé‚„ï¼Œå–æ™‰ä¹‹æœæ­Œå»ï¼Œä»¥å ±è‡¨è‘ä¹‹å½¹ä¹Ÿã€‚
In the sixth year, Duke Xiang of Lu paid court to Jin. Luan Cheng of Jin committed a crime and fled to Qi. In the eighth year, Duke Zhuang of Qi secretly sent Luan Cheng to Quwo, with troops accompanying him. The Qi troops climbed Mount Taihang. Luan Cheng launched a rebellion from within Quwo and launched a surprise attack, entering Jiang. Jiang was unprepared. Duke Ping wanted to commit suicide. Fan Xian Zi stopped the duke and, with his followers, attacked Luan Cheng. Luan Cheng was defeated and fled back to Quwo. Quwo attacked Luan Cheng. He died, and they exterminated the entire Luan clan lineage. Luan Cheng was Luan Shu's grandson. His attack on Jiang was plotted in collusion with the Wei clan. Qi Zhuang Gong heard that Cheng was defeated, then returned, took Jin's Zhao Ge and departed, to repay the Lin Zi campaign.

åå¹´ï¼Œé½Šå´”æ¼å¼’å…¶å›èŠå…¬ã€‚ æ™‰å› é½Šäº‚ï¼Œä¼æ•—é½Šæ–¼é«˜å”å»ï¼Œå ±å¤ªè¡Œä¹‹å½¹ä¹Ÿã€‚
In the tenth year, Cui Zhu of Qi assassinated his ruler, Duke Zhuang. Taking advantage of Qi's internal disorder, Jin attacked and defeated Qi at Gaotang, then withdrew. This was revenge for the Taihang campaign.

In the fourteenth year, Wu Yan Ling Ji Zi came as envoy and spoke with Zhao Wen Zi, Han Xuan Zi, and Wei Xian Zi, saying: 'Jin country's governance ultimately belongs to these three houses.'

åä¹å¹´ï¼Œé½Šä½¿æ™å¬°å¦‚æ™‰ï¼Œèˆ‡å”å‘èªã€‚ å”å‘æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ™‰ï¼Œå­£ä¸–ä¹Ÿã€‚ å…¬åšè³¦ç‚ºè‡ºæ± è€Œä¸æ¤æ”¿ï¼Œæ”¿åœ¨ç§é–€ï¼Œå…¶å¯ä¹…ä¹ï¼ã€ æ™å­ç„¶ä¹‹ã€‚
In the nineteenth year, Qi sent Yan Ying to Jin, where he conversed with Shu Xiang. Shu Xiang said: 'Jin is in its final generation. The duke imposes heavy taxes for towers and ponds but does not care about governance. Governance is in private gates. How can it endure long!' Yan Zi agreed to this.

In the twenty-second year, they attacked Yan. In the twenty-sixth year, Duke Ping passed away, and his son Yi ascended as Duke Zhao.

Duke Zhao died in the sixth year of his reign. The six ministers grew powerful while the ducal house declined. His son Qu Ji ascended as Duke Qing.

In the sixth year of Duke Qing's reign, King Jing of Zhou died, and his sons vied for the throne. The six ministers of Jin pacified the royal court's disorder and installed King Jing.

In the ninth year, the Ji clan of Lu expelled their ruler Duke Zhao, who took up residence at Qianhou. In the eleventh year, Wei and Song sent envoys requesting that Jin restore the ruler of Lu. Ji Ping Zi privately bribed Fan Xian Zi. Xian Zi received it, then told the Jin lord: 'The Ji clan has no crime.' In the end, they did not restore the ruler of Lu.

åäºŒå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰ä¹‹å®—å®¶ç¥å‚’å­«ï¼Œå”å‘å­ï¼Œç›¸æƒ¡æ–¼å›ã€‚ å…­å¿æ¬²å¼±å…¬å®¤ï¼Œä¹ƒé‚ä»¥æ³•ç›¡æ»…å…¶æ—ã€‚ è€Œåˆ†å…¶é‚‘ç‚ºåç¸£ï¼Œå„ä»¤å…¶å­ç‚ºå¤§å¤«ã€‚ æ™‰ç›Šå¼±ï¼Œå…­å¿çš†å¤§ã€‚
In the twelfth year, Jin's ancestral house Qi Xi's grandson and Shu Xiang's son mutually disliked each other at the lord's court. The six ministers wanted to weaken the ducal house, so they used the law to exterminate their entire clan. They divided the clan's territories into ten counties, each appointing their own son as magistrate. Jin grew increasingly weak, while the six ministers all became powerful.

In the fourteenth year, Duke Qing passed away, and his son Wu ascended as Duke Ding. In the eleventh year of Duke Ding's reign, Yang Hu of Lu fled to Jin, where Zhao Yang, Lord Jian, gave him asylum. In the twelfth year, Confucius became prime minister of Lu.

åäº”å¹´ï¼Œè¶™é…ä½¿é‚¯é„²å¤§å¤«åˆï¼Œä¸ä¿¡ï¼Œæ¬²æ®ºåˆï¼Œåˆèˆ‡ä¸­è¡Œå¯…ã€èŒƒå‰å°„è¦ªæ”»è¶™é…ï¼Œé…èµ°ä¿æ™‰é™½ã€‚ å®šå…¬åœæ™‰é™½ã€‚ è€æ«Ÿã€éŸ“ä¸ä¿¡ã€é­ä¾ˆèˆ‡èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œç‚ºä»‡ï¼Œä¹ƒç§»å…µä¼èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œã€‚ èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œåï¼Œæ™‰å›æ“Šä¹‹ï¼Œæ•—èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œã€‚ èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œèµ°æœæ­Œï¼Œä¿ä¹‹ã€‚ éŸ“ã€é­ç‚ºè¶™é…è¬æ™‰å›ï¼Œä¹ƒèµ¦è¶™é…ï¼Œå¾©ä½ã€‚ äºŒåäºŒå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰æ•—èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ°ï¼ŒäºŒå­å¥”é½Šã€‚
In the fifteenth year, Zhao Yang sent the magistrate of Handan, Wu, but Wu was not trusted and wanted to kill him. Wu, together with Zhong Xing Yin and Fan Ji She, launched a personal attack on Zhao Yang. Yang fled and fortified himself in Jinyang. Duke Ding laid siege to Jinyang. Xun Yue, Han Bu Xin, and Wei Chi were enemies of the Fan and Zhong Xing clans, so they diverted their troops to attack the Fan and Zhong Xing. The Fan and Zhong Xing clans rebelled. The ruler of Jin attacked them and defeated the Fan and Zhong Xing. The Fan and Zhong Xing fled to Zhaoge and fortified themselves there. Han and Wei interceded with the ruler of Jin on Zhao Yang's behalf, and he was pardoned and restored to his position. In the twenty-second year, Jin defeated the Fan and Zhong Xing clans, and their two leaders fled to Qi.

ä¸‰åå¹´ï¼Œå®šå…¬èˆ‡å³ç‹å¤«å·®æœƒé»ƒæ± ï¼Œçˆ­é•·ï¼Œè¶™é…æ™‚å¾ï¼Œå’é•·å³ã€‚
In the thirtieth year, Duke Ding met King Fu Chai of Wu at Huang Pool and disputed precedence. Zhao Yang was present at the time, and in the end Wu was given seniority.

In the thirty-first year, Tian Chang of Qi assassinated his ruler Duke Jian and installed Duke Jian's younger brother Ao as Duke Ping. In the thirty-third year, Confucius passed away.

In the thirty-seventh year, Duke Ding passed away, and his son Zao ascended as Duke Chu.

In the seventeenth year of Duke Chu's reign, Zhi Bo, together with Zhao, Han, and Wei, divided the lands of the Fan and Zhong Xing clans among themselves as their own territories. Duke Chu was furious and appealed to Qi and Lu, hoping to attack the four ministers with their help. The four ministers were alarmed, so they launched a counterattack against Duke Chu. Chu Gong fled to Qi and died on the road. Therefore Zhi Bo then established Zhao Gong's great-grandson Jiao as Jin lord. This was Ai Gong.
132
å“€å…¬å¤§çˆ¶é›ï¼Œæ™‰æ˜­å…¬å°‘å­ä¹Ÿï¼Œè™Ÿç‚ºæˆ´å­ã€‚ æˆ´å­ç”Ÿå¿Œã€‚ å¿Œå–„çŸ¥ä¼¯ï¼Œèš¤æ­»ï¼Œæ•…çŸ¥ä¼¯æ¬²ç›¡å¹¶æ™‰ï¼Œæœªæ•¢ï¼Œä¹ƒç«‹å¿Œå­é©•ç‚ºå›ã€‚ ç•¶æ˜¯æ™‚ï¼Œæ™‰åœ‹æ”¿çš†æ±ºçŸ¥ä¼¯ï¼Œæ™‰å“€å…¬ä¸å¾—æœ‰æ‰€åˆ¶ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯é‚æœ‰èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œåœ°ï¼Œæœ€å½Šã€‚
Ai Gong's grandfather Yong was Jin Zhao Gong's youngest son and was styled Dai Zi. Dai Zi begot Ji. Ji was good to Zhi Bo but died early. Therefore Zhi Bo desired to completely annex Jin but did not dare, so he established Ji's son Jiao as lord. At this time, all of Jin country's governance was decided by Zhi Bo. Jin Ai Gong could not have any control. Zhi Bo then possessed the Fan and Zhong Xing lands and was the strongest.

å“€å…¬å››å¹´ï¼Œè¶™è¥„å­ã€éŸ“åº·å­ã€é­æ¡“å­å…±æ®ºçŸ¥ä¼¯ï¼Œç›¡å¹¶å…¶åœ°ã€‚
In Ai Gong's fourth year, Zhao Xiang Zi, Han Kang Zi, and Wei Huan Zi together killed Zhi Bo and completely annexed his lands.

In the eighteenth year, Ai Gong died, and his son You Gong Liu was established.

In You Gong's time, Jin feared and instead attended court to the Han, Zhao, and Wei lords. They only possessed Jiang and Qu Wo. The remainder all entered the three Jin.

In the fifteenth year, Wei Wen Hou was first established. In the eighteenth year, You Gong was licentious with women. At night he secretly left the city, and a thief killed You Gong. Wei Wen Hou with troops executed Jin's disorder and established You Gong's son Zhi. This was Lie Gong.

In Lie Gong's nineteenth year, Zhou Wei Lie Wang granted Zhao, Han, and Wei all to be appointed as feudal lords.

äºŒåä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œçƒˆå…¬å’ï¼Œå­å­å…¬é ç«‹ã€‚ å­å…¬ä¹å¹´ï¼Œé­æ­¦ä¾¯åˆç«‹ï¼Œè¥²é‚¯é„²ï¼Œä¸å‹è€Œå»ã€‚ åä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œå­å…¬å’ï¼Œå­éœå…¬ä¿±é…’ç«‹ã€‚ æ˜¯æ­²ï¼Œé½Šå¨ç‹å…ƒå¹´ä¹Ÿã€‚
In the twenty-seventh year, Lie Gong died, and his son Xiao Gong Si was established. In Xiao Gong's ninth year, Wei Wu Hou was first established. He attacked Han Dan but was not victorious and departed. In the seventeenth year, Xiao Gong died, and his son Jing Gong Ju Jiu was established. This year was Qi Wei Wang's first year.

In Jing Gong's second year, Wei Wu Hou, Han Ai Hou, and Zhao Jing Hou extinguished Jin's remnant and three-way divided its lands. Jing Gong was moved to become a commoner. Jin was absolutely not sacrificed to.

The Grand Historian said: Jin Wen Gong was what the ancients called an enlightened lord. He fled and resided outside for nineteen years, extremely distressed and constrained. When he ascended the throne and performed rewards, he still forgot Jie Zi Tui. What about arrogant lords? Ling Gong was already assassinated. His descendants Cheng and Jing brought severity. To Li was greatly harsh. The grandees feared execution, and calamity arose. After Dao Gong, it daily declined, and the six ministers monopolized power. Therefore the lord's way of controlling their ministers below. Indeed not easy!
